Curtis, a former player and current assistant manager, believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 and that the team has not been the same since. He believes the current squad is good enough to stay up and reminds new players of the club's history and how far they have come.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his groundbreaking work in human genomics and synthetic biology. He is a controversial figure, often criticized for his competitive approach and disregard for scientific conventions. Despite this, his work has significantly accelerated the field of genomics. He is credited with creating the first complete genome of a free-living organism and leading the effort to create the world's first synthetic life form, Synthia. Dr. Venter's work has been driven by a sense of urgency, stemming from his experiences as a medic in the Vietnam War. He has also been a pioneer in oceanographic research, collecting and sequencing genomes from marine microbes. His work has the potential to revolutionize industries and address environmental challenges.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short compared to other European countries. The report, conducted by the Boston Consulting Group, found that only a small percentage of apprenticeships are at level three, equivalent to A-levels, and that England has a complicated patchwork of vocational qualifications compared to countries like Germany and Switzerland. The report calls for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, with a focus on level three and four qualifications, and argues that apprenticeships are crucial for social mobility and economic competitiveness. The Department for Education says they are reforming apprenticeships to improve standards and make them more responsive to employer needs.

British Paralympian Sarah Storey won the women's time trial at the Para-cycling Road World Championships in Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of the second-place finisher. This victory brings Storey closer to her 17th world title, which she can achieve in the road race on Saturday. Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, has won 22 medals across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. She is aiming for further Paralympic success at the 2016 Rio Games.

Hereford United was expelled from the Football Conference on June 10th, 2014, due to their inability to pay their debts. The club had been given multiple extensions to pay their creditors, but ultimately failed to meet the deadline. The club's financial struggles have been ongoing since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, with falling attendance exacerbating the situation. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust had offered to buy the club for Â£1 and clear their debts, but their offer was not accepted. The club was taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar in June 2014, but he was unable to save the club from expulsion.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after 61 caps for England. He was a member of two World Cup and two European Championship squads, but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps and scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova in 2014.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. Hogwood was a leading figure in the early-music movement, working with numerous orchestras worldwide and directing the AAM for over 30 years. He was known for his contributions to the field, including the AAM's first-ever complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments and his 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah, which is considered one of the top 20 recordings of all time. Hogwood's legacy is remembered by colleagues and musicians who credit him with fostering a new generation of musicians and promoting historically informed music.

A boy from Northern Ireland is unable to attend school due to special needs. His family has been waiting for a place at a special school since June, but all schools in the area are full. The family is concerned that this situation will continue to affect other families as the special needs school system is over capacity. The Education Authority is reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland and is working to ensure that places are available close to where children reside.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, which would make Rodney Parade a rugby venue. Newport County, who have a lease on the stadium until 2023, are expecting their contract to be honored. The WRU's takeover will be voted on May 9th. The WRU has stated their intention to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of relegation in League Two and could secure survival this weekend. Relegation to the National League would be a "massive" blow to the club and the city of Newport.

The passage tells the story of a Sierra Leonean man who was kidnapped by rebels as a teenager and forced to fight in the civil war. He escaped and later became involved in helping people during the Ebola crisis. He helped educate people about the virus, provided food and other support, and helped set up an Ebola treatment unit. He believes that young people have a role in changing the world and that investing in them is building the future.

Former "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" contestant, Mark Wright, is in talks to buy 20% of the Isthmian League Premier Division club, Billericay Town. Wright will become a club director if the deal is finalized. Billericay Town is currently eighth in the league, three points away from a play-off spot. The club was recently purchased by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has pledged to invest Â£10,000 a week.

Blackpool and Colchester United tied 1-1. Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso passed the ball to Jamille Matt, who scored. Colchester tied the game after 17 minutes when Kurtis Guthrie scored after a goalmouth scramble. Colchester had a chance to take the lead before halftime, but Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe saved a shot from George Elokobi. Blackpool had a chance to win the game 15 minutes before the end, but Tom Aldred missed a header. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was red-carded for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

The Fawley power station, which closed in 2013 after 40 years of operation, is being redeveloped into a "merchant city" with a marina, housing, and restaurants. The centerpiece of the Â£1 billion development will be a petal-shaped glass structure built around the power station's 198-meter-high chimney, which will be the tallest attraction south of London's Shard. The developers plan to start construction in 2018.

The British cycling team competed in the Hong Kong World Championships.  Ethan Latham won bronze in the men's omnium, while the men's team pursuit team lost to Italy for the bronze medal.  The women's team pursuit team finished fifth in the heats and did not qualify for the bronze medal ride.  Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.  The women's team pursuit team, with an average age of 19, is a young squad with a bright future.

Ross Kemp will reprise his role as Grant Mitchell in the British soap opera *EastEnders* for the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell.  Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006, will return to bring the Mitchell family back together for Peggy's death.  Grant Mitchell is one of the soap's most memorable characters, known for his family dramas, including an affair with his brother's wife, Kathy, and his brother marrying his ex-wife Sharon.

Liverpool defeated Tottenham Hotspur 2-1 at Anfield, with Sadio Mane scoring two goals within two minutes and 18 seconds. Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino expressed his disappointment with his team's performance, stating that they were not ready to fight for the Premier League title. He also expressed concern about Chelsea's potential 12-point lead if they win against Burnley. Tottenham has struggled on the road, winning only twice since September 24th, and has only won once in their last 17 away matches against top-six teams. Former Liverpool and Tottenham midfielder Danny Murphy criticized Tottenham's performance, highlighting their lack of pace and different mindset when playing away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). This is the PDP's first loss in a presidential election since the end of military rule in 1999, and they also lost key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna. The APC's victory is attributed to voter dissatisfaction with the PDP's 16 years in power, including allegations of corruption and failure to address the Boko Haram insurgency. The PDP will need to rebuild under new leadership, while the APC's control of Lagos state marks a significant shift in power dynamics.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will be held in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22. The festival will feature an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online information from signs and posters on the site. The app will also provide access to videos and band interviews. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan stated that the app will allow people around the world to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere.

The Department for Education has decided to terminate the funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary schools, both rated inadequate by Ofsted. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. The decision to terminate funding came after a series of reports into schools allegedly targeted as part of a hardline Muslim takeover. The reports found that Park View School had allowed a guest with known extremist views to speak to students as part of Islamic-themed assemblies. The reports also found that Oldknow Academy had been treating non-Muslims less favorably and segregating boys and girls. Parents at the schools have criticized Ofsted's reports and accused inspectors of bias.

Honey Rose, an eye specialist, is on trial for gross negligence manslaughter after the death of Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie. The prosecution alleges that Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during a routine eye exam, which led to a build-up of fluid in his brain and ultimately his death. The prosecution argues that Rose's conduct was "criminal" because it fell so far below the expected standard of a competent optometrist.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into having sex with a man he found on an adult website and filming the encounter. He also sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and the case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater sentencing powers. The judge stated that Weatherhogg, a first offender, posed a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland lost to Afghanistan in the first T20 match by six runs. Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson scoring 56 runs. Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs to spare, with Samiullah Shenwari scoring 56 runs and Mohammad Shahzad scoring 47 runs. The two teams will play again on Friday.

Barcelona paid Â£48.6 million for Neymar, but the total cost of the player, including signing-on fees, wages, agents fees, and taxes, is Â£106.8 million. The club has been investigated for misappropriating funds during the transfer, but they deny any wrongdoing. Barcelona has made a tax declaration of â¬13,550,830.56 to cover any potential discrepancies in their original tax payment.

British police officers have completed their review of the investigation into the murders of Hannah Witheridge and David Miller in Thailand. The officers will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims. The investigation is ongoing, with two Burmese suspects facing charges of murder, rape, and robbery. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the investigation, including the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects.

Scotlandâs womenâs national football team is on the verge of qualifying for the 2017 European Championships. The team has won all five of their qualifying matches and are in a strong position to qualify for the tournament in the Netherlands. The team is led by Bayern Munich forward, Jane Evans, who is one of 12 players on the team who play outside of Scotland. Evans believes that the experience of playing in top leagues abroad has helped the team improve and is a major factor in their success.

Apple has implemented a new security measure to prevent the theft of intimate photos from iCloud. The new measure, called two-factor authentication, requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering their username and password on an unfamiliar device. This measure prevents the use of software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which was previously used to download complete backups of iCloud data. While Apple has made two-factor authentication an opt-in choice, security experts recommend making it the default option.

The UKIP, which won the May election, spent the most at Â£2,956,737, followed by the Tories at Â£2,980,815. The Lib Dems spent Â£1,580,575 and Labour spent Â£1,027,339. The Green Party spent Â£534,249 and the SNP spent Â£267,372. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election campaign.

Barrow centre-back Anderson, 27, has joined Torquay United, while striker Keating, 21, has also joined the club. Anderson has played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, while Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Torquay manager Kevin Nicholson said that Anderson is a leader and Keating is hungry to prove himself. Torquay is currently four points above the relegation zone.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," which is a rare occurrence in horses without underlying health issues. While Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, he had never collapsed before and showed no signs of it on Saturday. Despite the rarity of this incident, the sport is determined to understand the cause and find ways to prevent it.

Several MSPs, including former First Minister Alex Salmond, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, and veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, are stepping down from the Scottish Parliament ahead of the May 5th election. Salmond, in his final speech, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and that the parliament should take on more responsibility for governing the country. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill, but insisted it did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign. McNeil, in his final speech, warned that Holyrood has things to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system, and that the parliament must be capable of meeting the challenge of accountability and scrutiny.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects in the 1989 Hillsborough disaster. The decision will be revealed at a meeting with victims' relatives. The 23 suspects include 15 from the Operation Resolve investigation into the causes of the disaster and 8 from an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A local resident witnessed this happening four times in two weeks. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the problem and is looking into ways to improve security, including the use of new tools to combat contraband. The Ministry of Justice denies the use of drones to smuggle contraband into the prison, but states that people caught smuggling packages over prison walls can be jailed for up to two years.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving after hitting 72-year-old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn with his car. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse for his actions, stating he understands Blackburn was a beloved member of the community and that he has thought of nothing but her and her family since the accident.

Scottish runner Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. Muir finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new personal best in the 5,000m. She is considering competing in the World Indoor Championships in March and is looking forward to future Olympic opportunities.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after attending a Christmas party.  Police are searching a three-acre wooded area near the River Liffey in Dublin, which is expected to take several weeks.  The search comes after a review of Deely's disappearance, which included enhancing CCTV footage from the night he went missing.  The footage shows Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside his workplace, the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street.  Police believe this man is the same one who followed Deely shortly after on Haddington Road.  Police have renewed their appeal for the man in the CCTV footage to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro defeated Stan Wawrinka in a thrilling match at Wimbledon. Del Potro, ranked 165th in the world, is playing in his first Grand Slam since 2014 after recovering from three wrist surgeries. He will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Nick Kyrgios also advanced to the third round after defeating Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match. Kyrgios will face Feliciano Lopez in the next round. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also won their matches.

Tunisia and Morocco both faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was threatened with expulsion after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (CAF) during the 2015 tournament. Morocco was banned from the 2017 qualifying draw after refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to fears of the Ebola virus. Both countries were able to participate in the 2017 tournament after apologizing to CAF and having their bans overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), respectively.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of success in Formula 1, is currently experiencing a period of decline. The team has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, but their recent performance has been disappointing. The slump began in 2013 with issues in chassis design, and despite improvements in the car, the Honda power unit has been a major obstacle. McLaren's greatest successes came during their partnership with Honda, including a dominant season in 1988. However, the team has faced scandals and setbacks in recent years, including a constructors' championship ban in 2007 and a "lie-gate" incident in 2009. Despite these challenges, McLaren's CEO Ron Dennis believes that the team is on the verge of a comeback, with a strong car and a renewed partnership with Honda. The team's success hinges on the performance of the Honda engine and the ability to arrest the decline.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was closed for three months after being found to have served alcohol past closing hours. The bar's license holder, Colleen O'Neill, was fined Â£3,000 and James Thomas was fined Â£1,000 for allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge stated that O'Neill had an "appalling record" and that the case was "as bad as I have come across."

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry hit eight three-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272 made in a single season. The Chicago Bulls, led by Pau Gasol's 16 points and 15 rebounds, overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised by the skills of YouTube star Bas van Velzen, who they thought was a competition winner. Van Velzen, a free-kick specialist, impressed the players with his skills and even scored a goal past the stand-in keeper. Van Velzen enjoyed the experience and was happy to see the players' reactions to his skills. He also surprised Balotelli by unveiling his famous slogan, "Why Always Me?"

A study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutations found that women who had their ovaries removed after diagnosis had a 62% lower risk of dying from breast cancer. The study also found that oophorectomy was associated with a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The authors of the study recommend that oophorectomy be considered as part of the treatment discussion for women with BRCA mutations and early-stage breast cancer.

On Easter Sunday, a married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina. The train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City, was delayed for almost three hours after the accident. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although one man fell ill during the delay and received treatment. The Lowes were pronounced dead at the scene.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. Toro, who fled Colombia after a confrontation with his boss, provided information that led to the prosecution of several cartel members, including Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, Toro was not granted citizenship and is now facing deportation. He fears for his life if he is returned to Colombia, as he believes he will be killed. The DEA has refused to help Toro with his citizenship, and he is currently living in the US illegally.

The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is investigating Vox Populi Registry Ltd., a Canadian company that has registered the '.sucks' domain name. ICANN is looking into whether Vox Populi's actions are illegal after receiving complaints from industry groups and companies like Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay. Vox Populi has been selling '.sucks' domains to celebrities and companies for around $2,499 a year, and they have reportedly been resold for around $2,000 a year.  ICANN is considering declaring Vox Populi in breach of its contract and seeking to change the registry's behavior if regulators find their actions are illegal.

A baby boy's body was found in a pond in 1988. After 27 years, police exhumed the body and used DNA to identify the mother. The mother admitted to concealing her pregnancy and giving birth to a stillborn baby. She placed the baby in the pond. The mother was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped. The police are now considering charging her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied with a headstone and named Peter after the church.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was found liable for the severe brain injuries sustained by his passenger, Kristopher Hicks, after Hicks jumped out of the moving car. Young, mistakenly believing Hicks was going to flee without paying, drove him back to the taxi rank as a form of punishment. Hicks, feeling unlawfully imprisoned, jumped out of the car while it was traveling at over 20 mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries. The judge ruled that Young's actions constituted unlawful imprisonment and awarded Hicks damages, though the exact amount is still to be determined.

On Wednesday night, tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri. Spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, Kansas, which moved northeast, missing Wichita but posing a threat to other communities.  Tornadoes were also reported in southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. In Missouri, a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and downed trees.  More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight fight in New Jersey. Rockhold is looking for his fourth consecutive win and a title shot, while Machida is confident he can upset Rockhold and earn himself a title shot. Rockhold plans to be aggressive and dominate Machida, while Machida plans to use his technique and strategy to win.

A light general aviation aircraft landed at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without its landing gear deployed. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, realized his mistake and managed to take off again, despite the plane's propellers hitting the runway. Georgaklis flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident, which is most commonly caused by human error or mechanical failure.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed his disappointment in Yaya Toure's performance this season, but has vowed to support the midfielder until the end of the season.  Pellegrini has also stated that Toure does not need a break, despite criticism of his performance.  Sportsmail revealed that Manchester City will listen to offers for Toure in the summer as they look to overhaul their aging squad.  Meanwhile, Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to Manchester City, citing the examples of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who did not play much after moving to the club.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive dubbed the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. Rancadore was convicted in absentia in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra and sentenced to seven years in prison. In February 2014, he lost his battle against extradition and was ordered to return to Italy to serve his sentence. However, it was discovered that his sentence expired in October 2014, and his European arrest warrant will be withdrawn. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished after a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still be heard by the Italian Supreme Court.

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three co-favorites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. The other co-favorites are Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. McCoy's book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will be finalized on Friday morning.

Rory McIlroy is aiming to win the Masters this year to complete his career grand slam. He believes that winning all four major championships is a significant accomplishment, as it requires success on different courses and under various conditions. McIlroy is confident in his ability to win at Augusta, having learned from his past experience of collapsing in the final round in 2011. He views that experience as a valuable lesson that helped him improve his game and mental fortitude. Despite the distractions of his personal life, McIlroy is looking forward to using the golf course as his sanctuary and focusing on his game at Augusta.

This week's trending stories included a photo of four rainbows in the sky after heavy rain in New York, a crackdown on exotic dancers performing at wakes in rural China, Robert Downey Jr.'s agitation at a UK interviewer's questions about his private life, the "Kylie Jenner Challenge" of lip plumping by sucking on a jar, a 102-year-old woman's prom-posal, Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer, a pregnant woman's "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" announcement, and a military dad photobombing his son.

In England, 272 children were hospitalized in the past year due to Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS), a disability caused by alcohol exposure in the womb.  The World Health Organization estimates that 1 in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure, which equates to about 7,500 babies per year.  FAS is a serious condition that can cause lifelong disabilities, and it is often underdiagnosed.  The government advises pregnant women to avoid alcohol, but some experts believe that the guidance should be changed to advise women not to drink at all during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew Mckerry, known as "Boomerang Boy" for his tendency to return home after committing crimes, attempted to rob a post office in Shildon, County Durham. He was tackled by the store owner, Sab Dhillon, and hit with a baseball bat by Dhillon's wife, Sam. Mckerry was arrested and sentenced to six years in prison for attempted robbery. Mckerry's criminal history dates back to age 12, with over 80 arrests by age 15. He was known for his numerous crimes, including shoplifting, aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary.

Valerie Jackson's son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's Syndrome, a rare genetic skin disease that causes his skin to appear red and scaly.  This has led to people mistaking his condition for child abuse, resulting in police being called on Valerie.  She has also been subjected to taunts and stares from strangers, and RJ has been denied entry to play centers.  Despite the challenges, Valerie remains positive and advocates for greater awareness of Netherton's Syndrome.

Protein World's "Are You Beach Body Ready?" ad campaign, featuring a bikini-clad model, has been met with backlash from feminists and body image campaigners. The ad has been defaced, received over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority, and a Change.org petition calling for its removal garnered over 50,000 signatures. Transport for London (TFL) has confirmed that the ads will be removed as scheduled, after the three-week advertising period paid for by Protein World. The company claims the image is unphotoshopped and has defended the campaign on social media, but has also received threats and a bomb threat that is being investigated by police.

Rail companies are raising fares by as much as 87% despite promises from both major political parties to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has written to First Great Western to request a review of their fare increases, which include an 87% increase on the route between London and the Cotswolds. Other companies, such as Virgin, have also raised fares, with some increases reaching 24.5%. The companies defend the increases by saying they are bringing fares in line with other services and that the increases affect only a small portion of their fares.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, was blinded in one eye after being hit with a brick thrown through his front door in Oldham, Greater Manchester. Young and his wife, Elaine, were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts when they heard a brick hit their window. Young went outside to confront the attackers, and was hit in the eye with another brick. Police are investigating the attack, but believe it may have been a case of "yobs messing around."

Tom Poynton, a wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a one-year contract extension after successfully returning from injuries sustained in a road accident that killed his father. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to the injuries but returned during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. The club is pleased with his return and hopes the new contract will give him the confidence to perform well this summer.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy from Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, after complaining of stomach pain. He underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy. After a year of battling the disease, Harley has been declared cancer-free. He will continue to have regular check-ups to ensure the cancer does not return.

Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood believes that 19-year-old Jack Grealish should focus on his club career before making a decision about his international future. Grealish has been impressive for Villa and is being pursued by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood wants Grealish to continue to earn a spot on the Villa first team, and believes that Grealish's international decision can wait. Sherwood compared the situation to Tottenham's Nabil Bentaleb, who chose to play for Algeria over France. Grealish's father, Kevin, agrees that his son should focus on his club career first.

Landing fees for private jets vary greatly around the world. The most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most expensive at Â£4,559 ($6,850). Other expensive airports include Narita International Airport in Tokyo, Kansai International Airport in Osaka, and Chubu Centrair International Airport in Nagoya. The only US airport in the top 10 is LaGuardia Airport in New York, which charges $3,950 (Â£2,630) for private jets. Other unexpected appearances in the top 10 include Dublin Airport and Salzburg Airport.

Katie Gallegos took her two dogs, Cooper and Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy took a few licks, Cooper gobbled the rest of the cone in one bite. Gallegos says Cooper always eats quickly and makes sure Daisy gets her fill first. The video of Cooper eating the ice cream has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream, but she insists it's fine because Cooper is healthy and her previous dog lived to be 19 years old. Gallegos also notes that the dogs enjoy "pup-uccinos" from Starbucks, which are just whipped cream in a cup.

Gary Locke, former assistant manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed as the permanent manager after a successful interim period. He joined the club last summer as assistant to Allan Johnston, but took over as manager in February when Johnston resigned. Locke has a three-year contract and has only lost one game in his seven games as manager.

A Florida mother is facing a school's threat to suspend her five-year-old autistic son for using essential oils to help him stay calm and focused. The school claims the oils are a distraction to other students, but the mother insists the oils have a positive impact on her son and that he has been using them all year without issue. The school district has since stated that they will not suspend the child, calling it a "health issue."

A fire destroyed a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, New York on Wednesday afternoon. The fire was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings and could be seen from three miles away. The fire started near a car parked by the complex, but the exact cause is still under investigation. The building manager, who lived and worked in the complex, lost everything in the fire.

Queen Elizabeth II, despite approaching her 89th birthday, still enjoys riding her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She has been riding since she was four years old and has a long history of owning and breeding horses. While she has cut back on riding in recent years due to a knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic equestrian and continues to breed fell ponies at her Hampton Court stud. The Queen is known for her love of horses and her refusal to wear a riding helmet, preferring to wear a silk scarf instead.

A dispute over noise in North Brisbane between neighbors Leon Yeaman, 55, and Phillip Pama, 28, ended in tragedy when Yeaman was killed by a single punch from Pama. Pama, a shift worker, was sleeping when Yeaman was making noise outside his home. Pama confronted Yeaman, and the situation escalated. Pama was granted conditional bail and is due back in court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher in Russia, was arrested for attempting to hire a hitman to kill her 15-year-old ex-boyfriend, Damian Vanya. Simonova had showered Vanya with gifts and money during their year-long relationship, but he ended it to be with a classmate. She offered a hitman 100,000 rubles (Â£1,400) to torture and kill Vanya, specifying that she wanted him to bleed to death before she "finished" him. Police set up a sting operation, sending an undercover officer to pose as the hitman. Simonova was arrested after handing over some money to the undercover officer. She faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya is relieved and hopes Simonova will never be released from prison.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's football manager, revealed that he prays every day but never about football. He also said that he never discusses football with his wife. Mourinho believes in God and prays for things in his personal life. He tries to separate his professional and family life. He also said that he is a good person and tries to support people he doesn't know.

Bob Barker, the original host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show for the first time in eight years. He hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven," before Drew Carey took over for the rest of the show.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. for attempted burglary and destruction of property. The incident occurred on Friday at 12:30 am on the 3200 block of D Street SE. Baldwin was arrested by Metropolitan Police officers returning to the scene of the alleged crime. The Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin is assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which works with the State Department on diplomatic activities. The arrest comes after a high-ranking supervisor was also placed on leave for alleged misconduct. The Homeland Security Department's Inspector General is investigating both incidents.

Atif Saeed, a freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture a photo of a lion at the city's safari park. Saeed crept within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to get a good shot. The sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion to Saeed's presence, forcing him to retreat quickly. Saeed said he was trying to capture the lion's character and status, and that he wouldn't do it again.

The NYPD is trying to identify a woman who was found dead in Brooklyn on March 22nd. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend. She had no identification on her, but had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg of a heart with a rose on top and a ribbon with the name "Monique" written on it. The cause of death is still unknown, and the NYPD is asking anyone with information to contact Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple, built a two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009. They were unable to afford a traditional home, so they built their own for $25,000. The home is powered by solar panels, with a gas-powered stove and hot water heater. Water comes from a nearby spring. The couple lives in Nelson, New Zealand, surrounded by nature.

A study by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten students who shared iPads in class scored significantly higher on early literacy tests than students who used their own iPads or did not use iPads at all. Blackwell believes that the collaborative learning aspect of sharing iPads is what leads to the improved literacy scores. She suggests that schools reconsider how they use tablets, especially in early grades, to maximize their effectiveness.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation in China after learning to walk on its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," has captured the hearts of thousands with its heartwarming video showing it learning to walk and balance. The piglet belongs to farmer Ms. Duan in Sichuan province and has become a local attraction.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by the car of Francesco Dracone. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center and released after receiving stitches for a cut on his leg. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to rain prior to the start. Dracone did not finish the race and placed 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, after a fight in their apartment in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Severiano dragged his wife into the garden, slammed her head against the concrete 11 times, punched her in the face 10 times, and then shot her in the face five times. Severiano confessed to the murder, stating that he was jealous of men looking at his wife. He was arrested after crashing a stolen car and faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," revealed in an interview that she struggled with anxiety and came close to suicide. She attributed her mental health struggles to a combination of factors, including stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feeling isolated from her family. Wilson believes that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that we need to acknowledge this connection to better address the increasing rates of anxiety among Australian women.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after she struck her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin found her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom and asked her to leave, but the woman refused. Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who won't leave a resident's home. Prosecutors dropped the charge against Curtin because they believed she was "completely justified in her outrage." Curtin's defense attorney stated that the ex-girlfriend was "jealous and bitter" that the boyfriend was in a relationship with Curtin and had been harassing and threatening her.
Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed reacting with disgust to a broccoli spear that her owner snuck into her treat mix. She chomped on the vegetable and then spit it out on the floor.

HSBC apologized after a link on their website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which were scrapped in 2011. The organizers allowed the registration for the website to expire, which allowed the pornographic site to take over the address. HSBC removed the hyperlink from their website and apologized for the inconvenience. They assured the public that their website remains secure.

A 13-year-old boy, Marcus, called 911 after a fire broke out in his home in Clinton, Maryland. He and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus calmly gave directions to firefighters, who rescued him and his sister through a window. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries.

Pictures of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast have emerged. The images were taken in Jervis Bay, New South Wales, and show the neon glow illuminating one of Australia's popular beaches. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton omitting light. A similar display was shown in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. The glow is caused by *Noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in the spring and autumn.

New tests can determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors and predict the likelihood of recurrence. These tests, such as Endopredict, can identify patients with a low risk of recurrence, potentially sparing them from chemotherapy and its associated side effects. While these tests are currently available privately, experts believe they should be offered on the NHS due to cost savings from avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy.

Over the past nine years, more than 25 women in the Royal Navy have been airlifted from ships due to pregnancy. This includes at least one woman from HMS Illustrious, which was nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew. The Ministry of Defence confirmed that there is a strict "no touching" rule in place at sea, suggesting that the women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. The data comes after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims she had a sexual relationship with a member of her crew.  Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after finding out they were pregnant. Between January 2006 and December 2013, 99 servicewomen on operations were flown back to the UK due to pregnancy. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo. The drone was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material. The discovery has raised concerns about the potential for terrorism involving drones, especially in light of the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit. The Japanese government is reviewing drone regulations and plans to take steps to prevent terrorism.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. He does this because he is afraid she will get lost if left alone. He ties a sash around both of their waists to ensure she doesn't fall off. He rides slowly to work so they can chat and his mother feels safe. At work, he checks on her frequently. He feels it is his duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to caring for her children.

A study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2% between 2005 and 2012. The study, published in the American Journal of Public Health, attributes the increase to rising rates of heavy drinking among women. The study defines heavy drinking as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men. Binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month. The study found that women's binge drinking rates rose by nearly 36% between 2002 and 2012, compared with 23% among men. Nationwide, the rate of binge drinking among women increased more than seven times the rate among men. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. Despite the increases in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is warning that doctors are performing too many Cesarean sections, putting the health of mothers and babies at risk. The WHO recommends that Cesarean sections should only be performed when medically necessary, as the procedure can lead to infections, complications, and even death. The WHO states that the ideal rate of Cesarean sections should be between 10% and 15%, but the rate in England has more than doubled since the early 1990s, with over 25% of women giving birth via Cesarean. The WHO also criticizes the current NHS guidelines, which allow women to have Cesarean sections even when there is no medical justification.

Michelle Filkins, 44, was arrested on April 17th after being found in the living room of a home she claimed to own. The owner, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins in his $800,000 summer home in Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard. Filkins fled the scene in a gray Nissan pickup truck after Conklin called the police. Police discovered a broken window covered by a blanket and later arrested Filkins after she attempted to re-enter the home. Filkins is facing charges of breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home, including a lamp and a painting, to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

Bella Crooke lost her phone at a friend's birthday party. The phone was found by a security guard and turned into the Albury police station. Police officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and puns on Bella's Facebook page in an attempt to find her. The posts included photos of the phone in various locations around the police station, including a holding cell. Bella eventually saw the posts and went to the police station to retrieve her phone. The police officers recognized her from her Facebook page and returned the phone to her. Bella was amused by the police's efforts and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old hippopotamus calf was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as the calf was tossed into the air and dragged through the water. The mother had stayed with her herd during the fight, believing it was safer than intervening.  A tour operator, Stacey Farrell, witnessed the event and described how the mother tried to protect her calf from other hippos before the fatal attack.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for Â£575,000, a fraction of the price of neighboring homes. However, the property has only three years left on its lease. The cost would work out to Â£191,000 per year, or Â£15,000 per month, which is around the going rate for renting a three-bedroom flat in the area. If a buyer decides to extend the lease, the property could be worth upwards of Â£6 million. The apartment is in need of renovation and is being sold by Russell Simpson. Estate agents say it is rare for properties with such short leases to come on the market, and the phone has been ringing off the hook about the Egerton Place apartment. However, Alex Newall from Hanover Private Office warns potential buyers that there will be a massive premium to pay to extend the lease.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage that affected registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada. The outage began in the early evening on the East Coast and in the late afternoon on the West Coast. The outage prevented staff from accepting credit cards or ringing up sales, but Starbucks workers were still accepting cash. The company offered free drinks and baked goods to customers before saying stores that had not already closed for the evening Friday were closing early. The outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. The company apologized to customers for any inconvenience or confusion and said they would update the statement once systems were back online.

Terrorist training and radicalization are occurring in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. Detective Constable Gareth Jones, from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, stated that individuals involved in these activities participate in seemingly ordinary activities within the community, but have ulterior motives.  The training locations are often used by the British military for training due to their rugged terrain.  Examples of terrorist activity in Wales include the 7/7 bombers white water rafting in North Wales, the arrest of three would-be terrorists in Cardiff, and the attendance of Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, at the former European Institute of Human Sciences in Highmead, near Llanybydder.  DC Jones stressed the importance of community intelligence in identifying and preventing terrorist activity.

An Omura's whale, a species rarely seen and thought to be extinct, was discovered on a beach in Western Australia. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The whale was a juvenile female and was identified through DNA profiling. The discovery is significant because very little is known about the species, which was only scientifically described in 2003. The whale's carcass has been buried and will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation.

Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, believes that women should not be president because their hormones make them irrational and prone to starting wars. This view is not unique, as many people believe women have a specific place in society and that place is not in leadership positions. The article argues that this bias against women is a serious problem that limits their potential and that it is important to have a discussion about ending gender bias. The article also points out that companies with more women in leadership roles make more money, and that children with involved fathers are happier, healthier, and more successful.

Actor Robert Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, is selling his collection of antiques at auction. The collection includes over 200 items, including a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, furniture, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. Hardy, a keen military historian, studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and is an expert on the medieval longbow. He is selling his collection because he is downsizing his home. The auction will take place on Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted for the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, in Winter Garden, Florida. He is on the run from police after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead. Shemansky has a history of mental illness and was on parole for battery on law enforcement. He was reportedly seen asking for a glass of water at the trailer park office shortly after the murder and was last seen fleeing on foot. Authorities are asking anyone with information about his whereabouts to contact them at 407-656-3636.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council awarded Eugene, Oregon the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The council bypassed the usual bidding process because they saw a unique opportunity to host the championships in the United States for the first time. Eugene previously lost a bid to host the 2019 event to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF Council believes this decision will allow them to access a key market and help the global development of athletics.

Leonie Granger, an aspiring model, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger befriended Hassan at a casino, showering him with gifts and taking advantage of his vulnerability. She then allowed her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and his friend, Nicholas Chandler, into Hassan's flat, where they tied him up, beat him to death, and stole his winnings. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season. His form has significantly dipped from the beginning of the season, when he looked likely to break the Premier League record for assists. Fabregas' former club, Barcelona, has commented on his traditional post-Christmas slump, noting that his contributions to the team gradually decrease as the season progresses. This trend seems to be continuing, as Fabregas has only one assist in the last five games. Despite his recent struggles, Chelsea still needs Fabregas to find his form again in order to win the Premier League title.

West Ham is in talks to sign Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford after he impressed during a trial with the club's academy. Beckford, 17, has also received offers from clubs in Belgium. West Ham is also planning to offer the cheapest season tickets in the Premier League to fill their new 54,000-capacity stadium at the Olympic Stadium.

Mike Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was assaulted by hunt saboteurs during a hunt on January 24th. Lane was kicked in the head and suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Despite a video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers, Wiltshire police have dropped the investigation due to insufficient evidence. The police have stated that the case is undetected but will be reopened if further evidence comes to light.

Adam Gadahn, an American citizen, was killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation. Gadahn was known as the American mouthpiece of al Qaeda, speaking against his native country on behalf of the terrorist organization. He was born in 1978 and converted to Islam in 1995. He left the United States for Pakistan in 1998 and joined al Qaeda, becoming its chief official English-language propagandist. He rose through the ranks in the tribal areas of Pakistan and appeared in al Qaeda videos threatening attacks on the United States and other Western countries. He was indicted by a federal grand jury in California in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda. Gadahn was married to a Muslim woman from Afghanistan and reportedly had at least one child.

Five-year-old Mai Zizhuo from China has become a viral sensation for his incredible basketball skills. The video shows him scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs at once. His skills have won him legions of fans across China, with many comparing him to the country's biggest basketball star, Yao Ming.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained to host a fashion show for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The show featured a collection of ten unisex pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways by the brand Ten Pieces, headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss. The show took place on a warm day with beautiful blue skies and sunshine. Guests enjoyed nibbles and drinks while watching the models walk through the empty pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, enjoyed a family trip to a safari park in Northern California. He posed with and fed a white tiger, as well as giraffes and sea lions. Khan announced that he will fight Chris Algieri on May 30th. Khan was under pressure to fight Kell Brook in June, but he is already in negotiations to fight someone else.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian teenager, was murdered by three Israelis in July. His name was added to the Israeli memorial wall commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism, but his family and the organization Almagor objected to his inclusion. They argued that his death was a rogue attack and not an act of terrorism. The National Insurance Institute of Israel has removed Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial wall following the complaints.

A young boy chases his cat around the garden in an attempt to use the cat as a pillow. The cat, initially still, gets up and moves when the boy lays down on him. The boy follows the cat and tries again, but the cat eventually goes inside. Later, the boy is seen feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his coaching job at a private academy after testifying about his past drug dealing. Kushner, who had passed a background check when he was hired in 2010, testified that he was arrested in 2007 for selling marijuana and had the charges expunged as part of a probationary sentence. He was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation. Kushner claims he never intended to deceive the school and believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges.

A chemical plant in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province, China, producing paraxylene (PX) experienced an explosion at an oil storage facility, injuring six people. The fire, which started after an oil leak, was put out by over 600 firefighters. The plant has a history of explosions, including one in 2013. The plant was originally intended for Xiamen, but was relocated to Zhangzhou in 2007 due to public concerns about pollution.

Aston Villa midfielder Jack Grealish made his first Premier League start on Tuesday against Queens Park Rangers. Grealish is known for wearing his socks low and using children's shin pads, which he says is a superstition he will continue. He is happy to have made his first start, but disappointed with the 3-3 draw.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, is in a critical condition with global and irreversible brain damage. Though she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and does not react to visitors or familiar voices. She has a tracheostomy in her throat and her condition has not changed in nearly three months. While her father, Bobby Brown, stated that she is awake and watching him, her grandmother, Cissy Houston, and a source with knowledge of her condition, stated that she is unresponsive. An attorney for the Brown family stated that Bobbi Kristina Brown's condition has improved and she will have a long life, but the quality of her life will not be known for years to come.

Russia is one win away from reaching the Fed Cup final after defeating Germany 2-0. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki in a hard-fought match that went to three sets, saving a match point in the second set. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets.

New South Wales residents are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. The storm is expected to bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, potentially impacting the Hunter region, which was severely affected by the previous storm. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that the new storm will hamper clean-up efforts, as they still have over 4,000 jobs to complete from the previous storm. The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" music video, denied claims that she attempted suicide. Moric posted photos of bruises on her arms on Instagram and explained that she was hospitalized due to low blood pressure after a fall. She stated that she was recovering at home and that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time of the incident. Italian media reported that Moric's boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, confirmed the suicide attempt, but Moric denied this.

The British public is hoping for a baby princess and favors the name Diana for the second child of Kate and William. The poll revealed that 12% of people want the baby to be named after William's mother, Diana, the Princess of Wales. The second and third most popular names for a girl are Alice and Charlotte. If the baby is a boy, 13% of people want him to be named James. The poll also revealed that 68% of people support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and injured 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker, in Khost, Afghanistan. The bombing occurred near a group of protesters who were on their way to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves will be leaving Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves has been with Barcelona for seven years, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles. His agent, Dinorah Santana, stated that Alves rejected a three-year contract extension that required him to play in 60% of the club's matches.

Boca Juniors player Pablo Osvaldo has urged former teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo believes that the two Italian legends would be a good fit for Boca Juniors and that the fans would love to have them play at La Bombonera. He believes that Pirlo and Totti have a South American style of play and would be perfect for the club.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lee Lewis Ferguson was thrown from his horse in a spectacular fall at Wincanton. The fall was caught on video and has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online. Ferguson, who only sustained a cut on his nose, was back riding the next day and is not deterred from returning to racing.

James Haskell, captain of the London Wasps, posted a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram to celebrate the release of the new Avengers movie. Haskell, who returned to the Wasps in 2012 after playing rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand, has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and has become a key member of the England squad.

Wide-leg trousers are a popular trend for spring 2015. They are a welcome alternative to skinny jeans and can be styled in many ways. The key to pulling off this look is to keep the top half simple and pair the trousers with high heels. Denim is the easiest way to achieve the trend, and many designers, including Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney, have showcased wide-leg trousers in their spring 2015 collections.

The University of Michigan initially canceled a screening of the film "American Sniper" as part of a student social event series, UMIX, due to a petition signed by over 200 students who objected to the film's portrayal of the Iraq War. However, after a counter-petition was created, the university reversed its decision, stating that the initial cancellation was a mistake and that the university values freedom of expression and the right of students to make their own choices. The university will also offer a screening of the family-friendly film "Paddington" for those who do not wish to attend "American Sniper."

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty after they allegedly set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia. The quokka, a small marsupial native to Australia, survived the incident but was singed by the flames. The tourists were evicted from the island and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer, was able to see herself dancing for the first time in years.  Barker, who danced in famous New York City nightclubs in the 1930s and 1940s, had lost all of her photographs and memorabilia.  Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers created a video of "soundies" for Barker to watch at her nursing home.  Barker was thrilled to see herself dancing again.

A recent study found that car washing is becoming less common in Britain, with a third of men admitting they have never washed their own car. The study also revealed that three-quarters of women never wash their own car. The decline in car washing is attributed to factors such as the rise of hand car washes, the increasing size of cars, and the lack of time. The study found that people are more likely to wash their own cars during holidays, and that car owners in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield are more likely to wash their own cars than those in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh.

Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard is set to play his last game at Anfield in the FA Cup final on May 30th before moving to LA Galaxy.  Martin Skrtel, a Liverpool defender, has praised Gerrard's impact on the team since he arrived in 2008, but believes the team can overcome the challenge of replacing him. Skrtel believes that Gerrard is one of the best players in the world and that Liverpool will never be the same without him.  Skrtel also believes that Liverpool has players who can replace Gerrard, but they will need help to do so.

Jack Nicklaus, at the age of 75, aced the fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This was his first ace on the course. Five aces were made during the contest, tying the record set in 2002. Camilo Villegas also aced the fourth hole and the eighth hole, but lost the contest to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus won his first Masters in 1963 and his sixth in 1986. He is one of five golfers to complete the career grand slam, which Rory McIlroy can achieve if he wins his third major in a row.

On Wednesday night, tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri. Spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, Kansas, which moved northeast, missing Wichita but posing a threat to other communities.  Tornadoes were also reported in southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. In Missouri, a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and downed trees.  More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Robert Bates, a reserve deputy for the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for the fatal shooting of Eric Harris. Bates claims he meant to use a taser but accidentally shot Harris with his gun. The family of Eric Harris is upset that Bates is going on vacation to the Bahamas during this time. Bates' lawyer claims he was properly trained and released his training documents to prove it. Two deputies involved in the arrest of Harris have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor is preparing to fight Jose Aldo for the featherweight title on July 11th. McGregor has a new tiger tattoo on his stomach and claims to have more motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it. The two fighters have a contentious relationship, which was highlighted when McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott was criticized for drinking a schooner of beer in six seconds at a sporting event. Critics, including cultural studies professor Julie Robert, argued that his actions glorified binge drinking and perpetuated the stereotype that heavy drinking is a sign of masculinity. They also criticized the media and government officials for their reactions to the event, which they felt further normalized irresponsible drinking practices. However, Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, arguing that his actions were harmless and that he is a healthy individual who sets a good example.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, Indiana, since a short-term needle exchange program was approved by Governor Mike Pence. The number of confirmed HIV cases has risen to 120, with 10 preliminary positive cases. The outbreak has occurred among intravenous drug users, primarily involving the use of the painkiller Opana. The needle exchange program has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, with about 1,400 used syringes returned. The future of the program is uncertain, as Governor Pence opposes needle exchanges and the Senate is unsure whether to support legislation that would allow needle exchange programs in other counties. The House has approved a bill that would allow the 23 Indiana counties with the highest rate-per-population of hepatitis C to establish their own needle-exchange programs. The bill is scheduled for a hearing on Monday in a house-senate conference committee.

A man tested his girlfriend's knowledge of his favorite football club, Arsenal, with a comprehensive exam. The test included multiple choice questions, tables to complete, and "in your own words" sections. The girlfriend, Saskia, scored an impressive 87%, earning an "A" grade and avoiding a breakup. While some found the test excessive, others praised the boyfriend's dedication and Saskia's knowledge, calling her "proper gf material."

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an undercover informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. Toro, who fled Colombia after a confrontation with his boss, provided information that led to the prosecution of several cartel members, including Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, Toro was denied citizenship and is now facing deportation. He fears for his life if he is returned to Colombia, where he would be targeted by former associates. The DEA has refused to help Toro with his citizenship, and he is currently living in the US illegally.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal says he is looking forward to the derby against Manchester City at Old Trafford, but will be without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw due to fitness concerns. Van Gaal is hoping for a win to move United closer to a top-three finish and avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture. He acknowledges that City will be a tough opponent, but is confident that his team has learned from their previous loss to City. Van Gaal is also excited to experience the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford for the first time since joining the club.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against rising ticket prices at the Emirates Stadium during their Premier League match. Fans from both clubs left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of the game to show their discontent with the increasing cost of attending matches. The protest came after the Premier League announced a Â£5.14 billion TV rights deal, while ticket prices for the game started at Â£64. Fans displayed banners inside and outside the stadium, expressing their frustration with the high prices and calling for tangible reductions. The protest was organized by the Black Scarf Movement, Spirit of Shankly, and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups, who believe that football has become too focused on money and has lost touch with its fans.

Star Reader, a newborn baby from Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition that affects about 1 in 16,000 babies. After an unsuccessful attempt to unclog her bile ducts, Star needed a liver transplant. Her parents were not suitable matches, but her maternal aunt, Shanell, volunteered and was a perfect candidate. Shanell donated part of her liver to Star, who underwent the transplant in November and has since made a full recovery.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake teamed up to take on Loic Remy and Willian in a series of challenges for Audi. The challenges included shooting balls into the boot of a car, sinking balls into a convertible Audi from long range, and playing tennis over the top of an Audi R8 V10 Plus. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, but Remy and Willian won the final round, which involved shooting at cars from long range.  Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror off one of the Audis during the final challenge.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, was sentenced for causing a fatal car crash that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus' death. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison. Dellinger drove his pickup truck across a median at over 100 mph, crashing into an oncoming SUV, killing Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancÃ©, Jason Timmons. Dellinger's attorneys claimed he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, the effects of a psychiatric drug overdose and Prozac, and the advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears. Spears was found guilty of second-degree murder after she poisoned her son with salt while he was hospitalized. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger and frustration on Facebook, stating that he hoped Spears would die in prison. Prosecutors argued that Spears poisoned her son for attention, while her lawyer claimed she was innocent and blamed the hospital for negligence.

Australia will receive a new influenza vaccine in April 20 that will protect against two new strains of influenza, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States during the northern winter. The vaccine was modified after the previous version did not provide adequate protection against these strains. The new vaccine will be available for free to high-risk groups, such as the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians. Experts recommend that everyone get the vaccine, as it also provides protection against the H1N1 strain.

Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois is facing criticism and potential budget cuts. The tomb was recently criticized in National Geographic magazine for its "office lobby" aesthetic. The state of Illinois is facing a financial crisis and Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb. The tomb has also been subject to budget cuts, resulting in reduced hours and staff. Despite these challenges, the tomb has undergone recent renovations and remains a popular tourist destination.

This article discusses nine fashion trends from the 1990s and early 2000s that are making a comeback. The trends include bucket hats, camouflage print, double denim, Ugg boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. The article provides examples of celebrities who wore these trends in the past and who are wearing them again today.

This week's trending stories include: a photo of four rainbows in the New York sky, a crackdown on exotic dancers performing at wakes in China, Robert Downey Jr.'s frustration with a UK interviewer, the "Kylie Jenner Challenge" of lip plumping by sucking on a jar, a 102-year-old woman going to prom, a prom-posal that referenced bombs, Ewan McGregor playing Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's transformation for "Black Mass," a creative pregnancy announcement, and a military dad photobombing his son.

Serena Williams won her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets to advance to the semi-finals.  Williams will face Simona Halep for a spot in the finals.  Andy Murray also celebrated his 500th career victory at the Miami Open.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and cafe owner, was shot and killed in Karachi after hosting a discussion on the disappearance of people in Baluchistan. Mahmud was known for her outspoken views on human rights and women's entrepreneurship, and her cafe was a popular gathering place for young Pakistanis seeking freedom of thought.
