East End Park was a major league baseball stadium in Cincinnati, Ohio. The song "In the End" was written by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown's solo career began with the release of "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

"Mohra" is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai and starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. The film was released on July 1, 1994, and became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year. It received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally, Divya Bharti was cast as the female lead and filmed many scenes, but after her death, Raveena Tandon replaced her. The film is also known for its popular songs.
The song "Hourglass" was created by the British electronic duo Disclosure. The song is featured on singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.
Shane Black is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is best known for writing the 1987 action film *Lethal Weapon* and directing the 2005 film *Kiss Kiss Bang Bang*.
"A View to a Kill" (1985) is the 14th James Bond film and the last to feature Roger Moore as the secret agent.
Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, encompassing most of western New Guinea. It was previously known as Irian Jaya and included all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though some believe his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez began her music career in 1999 with her debut album, "On the 6." In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week with the release of her second album, "J.Lo," and the film, "The Wedding Planner." After her second divorce, Lopez's relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her third album, "This Is Me... Then." She later married Marc Anthony and rebounded with the success of the film, "Shall We Dance?" After giving birth to twins in 2008, Lopez returned to prominence in 2011 with her role as a judge on "American Idol" and the release of her most commercially successful single, "On the Floor."

Working animals are domesticated animals trained to perform tasks for humans. These animals can be close companions, like guide dogs, or used for labor, like draft horses. They can also be trained for milking or herding. While wild animals can be tamed and trained, they are rarely used for work due to their lack of trustworthiness and mild temper.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Billboard magazine publishes two music charts: Top Latin Albums, the most important chart for Spanish language albums in the American market, and Regional Mexican Albums, a genre-specific chart.

"Vedam" is a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi. The film stars Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.
Men in Black II is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.
Sancho Panza is the squire of Don Quixote in the novel *Don Quixote* by Miguel de Cervantes. He is known for his humorous, ironic, and witty comments, called "sanchismos."
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
The world premiere of Hedda Gabler, a play by Henrik Ibsen, took place on January 31, 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich. Ibsen was present at the premiere.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company located in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth is an English actor and director born on May 14, 1961.

Juventus Football Club, nicknamed Juve, is an Italian professional football club founded in 1897 by young students in Turin. It is the second oldest active football club in Italy, after Genoa. The club's traditional home kit is black and white stripes, and they currently play at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis had supporting and minor roles in several films and television series in the late 1990s and early 2000s, including the films *Kate & Leopold* (2001) and *Far from Heaven* (2002), and the television series *Law & Order: Special Victims Unit*.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress. She is known as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer and "The Queen of Porn." Jameson began acting in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamor model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a team in the National Basketball Association (NBA) and are part of the Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually broadcast via pay-per-view television.  Starrcade was a tradition that began in the 1960s and 1970s with JCP holding major professional wrestling events on Thanksgiving and Christmas, mostly at Greensboro Coliseum.

Jack Ryan Falahee is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh on the ABC television legal drama *How to Get Away with Murder* and Benjamin Stringfellow on the PBS historical drama *Mercy Street*.

Seohyun, a member of the popular South Korean girl group Girls' Generation, debuted as a solo artist on January 17, 2017, with her mini album *Don't Say No*. This makes her the third member of Girls' Generation to debut as a solo artist.  She is also known for her acting career, having starred in stage musicals such as *Moon Embracing the Sun*, *Gone with the Wind*, and *Mamma Mia*.

The Apple II, designed by Steve Wozniak, was one of the first successful mass-produced home computers. The Apple II series, manufactured by Apple Computer, was introduced in 1977. Steve Wozniak, nicknamed "Woz," is an American inventor, engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and entrepreneur who co-founded Apple Inc.
A&E is an American cable and satellite television channel owned equally by the Hearst Corporation and the Walt Disney Company.

L.A. Reid has held several high-ranking positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group, founder and CEO of Hitco Music Publishing, and co-founder of LaFace Records.

There are two films titled "Veeram (Valour)": one is a 2014 Indian Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and the other is a 2016 Indian epic historical drama film written and directed by Jayaraj.

"Home for the Holidays" is a horror film that premiered on ABC in 1972, starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan. A second film with the same name was released in 1995, starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Killam is an American actor, comedian, and writer born on April 1, 1982.
The Sex Factor is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster where eight men and eight women compete to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer born on July 15, 1973.
Island Records is a British-American record label owned by Universal Music Group.
Sikkim is a state located in northeastern India.
Christa McAuliffe was a social studies teacher at Concord High School in New Hampshire from 1983.
Ron Weasley is a fictional character in J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter series.
"Reign Over Me" is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder, produced by his brother Jack Binder, and distributed by Columbia Pictures. The film was released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Kaepernick is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent. He was born on November 3, 1987.

Sheryl Lee appeared in the film *CafeÌ Society* in 2016 and reprised her role as Laura Palmer in the Showtime revival of *Twin Peaks* in 2017. Sheryl Lee Ralph played Madame Morrible in the Broadway production of *Wicked* in 2016.
Matteo Renzi, born January 11, 1975, is an Italian politician who served as Prime Minister of Italy from February 2014 to December 2016.
The animated film "The Road to El Dorado" stars Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh, Armand Assante, Jim Cummings, Edward James Olmos, Tobin Bell, and Rosie Perez.

Selena Gomez's song "Same Old Love" is from her second studio album, *Revival*, released in 2015. The album debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 chart, and the first three singles, including "Same Old Love," topped the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the United States.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal music originated in the late 1960s and early 1970s in the United Kingdom and the United States.  Bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon, part of the new wave of British heavy metal, emerged in the late 1970s and continued the genre's tradition.
Ashton Kutcher starred in several romantic comedies, including "Guess Who," "A Lot Like Love," "What Happens in Vegas," and "No Strings Attached."

Topman is a British men's clothing retailer owned by the Arcadia Group, which also owns several other clothing brands. Topman has stores throughout the United Kingdom and in six Irish cities and towns.

The Industrial Revolution transformed Wales from an agricultural society to an industrial nation. The development of mining and metallurgical industries, particularly the South Wales Coalfield, led to a rapid increase in the country's population.
Tool is a band that has won three Grammy Awards, toured internationally, and had chart-topping albums in multiple countries.
YouTube is an American video-sharing website headquartered in San Bruno, California. It is the second most popular website in the world, according to web traffic analysis company Alexa Internet.
Sidse Babett Knudsen is a Danish actress born on November 22, 1968. She works in theatre, television, and film.
Conrad Dunn's first major film role was as Francis "Psycho" Soyer in the 1981 film "Stripes."  The film also featured the first significant roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, and Judge Reinhold.
The film "Raees" stars Shah Rukh Khan, Mahira Khan, and Nawazuddin Siddiqui.
Asylum Records is an American record label founded in 1971 by David Geffen and Elliot Roberts.
Trollhunters is an American animated fantasy television series created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix. It was produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians by the Ottoman government between 1915 and 1923. The Ottoman government also targeted other indigenous and Christian ethnic groups, such as the Assyrians and Ottoman Greeks, for extermination.
Marcus Morgan Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist born on October 4, 1967.

William Jefferson Clinton, born August 19, 1946, served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001. His first inauguration as president took place on January 20, 1993, on the West Front of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle is an English director, producer, screenwriter, and theatre director known for films such as *Shallow Grave*, *Trainspotting*, *The Beach*, *28 Days Later*, *Sunshine*, *Slumdog Millionaire*, *127 Hours*, and *Steve Jobs*. *The Beach*, a 2000 adventure drama film directed by Boyle, is based on the 1996 novel of the same name by Alex Garland, adapted for the film by John Hodge.

The image of a dress went viral on social media, generating over 10 million tweets in the first week alone. The dress was the subject of much discussion, with users using hashtags such as #thedress, #whiteandgold, and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand was a British Army officer who lived from January 22, 1917 to June 11, 2006.
Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses audio or visual messages to promote products, services, or ideas. These messages are openly sponsored and non-personal.

The Others, a 2001 film, won eight Goya Awards, including Best Film and Best Director. It was the first English-language film to win Best Film at the Goyas, Spain's national film awards. The film was also nominated for six Saturn Awards, winning three: Best Horror Film, Best Actress for Nicole Kidman, and Best Supporting Actress for Fionnula Flanagan.
Ralph Fults was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist who was associated with Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow of the Barrow Gang.

The 14th Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, was born in 1935 in Taktser village, Tibet. He was recognized as the reincarnation of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937 and formally declared the 14th Dalai Lama in 1939. During the 1959 Tibetan uprising, the Dalai Lama fled to India, where he remains a refugee.

"Miracle at St. Anna" is a film set in World War II Italy that follows four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division who find refuge in a Tuscan village. The story is told through a flashback as a survivor recounts his experiences in 1980s New York.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

"Home for the Holidays" is a 1995 film starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and lived there for a significant portion of her early life. She later moved to Texas and then to San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg, born in Lawton, Oklahoma and raised in Anaheim, California, developed an interest in both the ocean and art as a child.

A mendicant is a person who practices religious asceticism by living a monastic life, either alone or with other monks. Monks may dedicate their lives to serving others or choose to live in prayer and contemplation outside of mainstream society. Many religious orders, including Catholic, Hindu, Sufi, Jain, and Buddhist, adhere to a mendicant way of life.
The Mod Squad was an American crime drama series that aired on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an upcoming American science fantasy western action horror film directed and co-written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona is the 48th state admitted to the United States, located in the southwestern region. It is the sixth largest and 14th most populous state.  Arizona is home to 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation, the largest in the state and the United States.
Smriti Mandhana is an Indian cricketer born on July 18, 1996, who plays for the Indian women's cricket team.

Emma Watson, born in Paris on April 15, 1990, is a French-British actress, model, and activist. She was raised in Oxfordshire and attended the Dragon School before training as an actress at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts.
Angela Bassett began her film career in the mid-1980s after graduating from Yale University with a bachelor's degree and drama school with a master's degree.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is the highest award given by NASA. It is awarded by the President of the United States on recommendations from the NASA Administrator. To receive the award, an astronaut must perform extraordinary feats while participating in a NASA space flight.
The Saw franchise has grossed over $873 million worldwide at the box office.
"Down with Love" is a romantic comedy film released in 2003.
Paul Nicholls is an actor best known for his roles as Joe Wicks in BBC's EastEnders and DS Sam Casey in ITV's Law & Order: UK.
Colombiana is a 2011 French action film co-written and produced by Luc Besson and directed by Olivier Megaton.
Rick Yune was a main cast member in the Netflix series Marco Polo until the show was cancelled in December 2016.

Kentucky is known for its horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
The film "Boyhood" follows the life of Mason Evans, Jr. from ages six to eighteen as he grows up in Texas with his divorced parents. Filming took place from 2002 to 2013.
The 2016 film Hush was produced by Trevor Macy through Intrepid Pictures and Jason Blum through Blumhouse Productions.
The Penibaetic System is the southernmost of the three mountain ranges that make up the Baetic System in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonobos is a clothing company that sells a full line of men's clothing, including suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear, and accessories. Topman is a British clothing retailer that is part of the Arcadia Group and has stores throughout the United Kingdom and Ireland.
"Roar" is the lead single from Katy Perry's fourth studio album, *Prism*, released in 2013.
Saturn Corporation, also known as Saturn LLC, was established on January 7, 1985, as a subsidiary of General Motors.

The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians by the Ottoman government between 1915 and 1923. While the Armenian Genocide is widely recognized as such, Turkey, the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, denies the term genocide and claims the mass killings were a necessary response to Armenian uprisings.
Muslims believe that the Quran was revealed to Muhammad by God through the angel Gabriel over 23 years, starting in 609 CE when Muhammad was 40 years old and ending in 632 CE, the year of his death.

The human brain, along with the spinal cord, makes up the central nervous system. The brain is comprised of the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum. The cerebrum is the largest part of the brain and contains several important structures, including the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus, limbic structures, claustrum, basal ganglia, basal forebrain structures, and circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting is a British comedy drama film released in 2017 that takes place in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.

AMGTV is an American television network that broadcasts a variety of family-friendly programming, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to, hunting and fishing, children's shows, and other features.

Sir Donald Bradman, also known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely considered the greatest batsman of all time. Even after his retirement, he remained a national icon and his opinion was highly valued. In 2001, Australian Prime Minister John Howard called him the "greatest living Australian."

Margaret Thatcher was the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990 and the Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990. She was the first woman to hold the office of Prime Minister and the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century. She became the first woman to lead a major political party in the United Kingdom when she defeated Edward Heath in the Conservative Party leadership election in 1975.
Randy "Macho Man" Savage was an American professional wrestler and commentator known for his time in the WWF (now WWE) and WCW.
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an American singer, songwriter, and actor whose career has spanned over five decades.

EA Black Box, a video game developer based in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, was founded in 1998 by former employees of Radical Entertainment. The company was later acquired by Electronic Arts (EA).

Baiae was a coastal resort in ancient Italy located on the northwest shore of the Gulf of Naples. Herculaneum, an ancient Roman town located near Mount Vesuvius, was destroyed by volcanic pyroclastic flows in 79 AD. The ruins of Herculaneum are located in the commune of Ercolano, Campania, Italy.  There are many culturally and historically significant sites near Naples, including the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum.

No Country for Old Men is a cat-and-mouse drama set in 1980 West Texas, starring Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem, and Josh Brolin. The film follows a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran. Tommy Lee Jones plays Sheriff Ed Tom Bell in the film.

Palo Alto is a city located in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, in the San Francisco Bay Area. The name "Palo Alto" means "tall tree" in Spanish, derived from the words "palo" (stick or tree) and "alto" (tall).

Albert Brooks, born Albert Lawrence Einstein, is an American actor, filmmaker, author, and comedian. He is known for his work in the film "Finding Dory," which was directed by Andrew Stanton and co-directed by Angus MacLane. The screenplay was written by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code is a method of transmitting text information using a series of on-off tones, lights, or clicks that can be understood by a skilled listener or observer. The code was designed so that the length of each character varies inversely to its frequency of occurrence in English, increasing the speed of communication. Morse code is less sensitive to poor signal conditions than voice and can be sent by improvised methods, making it one of the simplest and most versatile methods of telecommunication.
Alexandra Anna Daddario is an American actress born on March 16, 1986.

On December 12, 2005, a 6.5 magnitude earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan. The Hindu Kush mountain range, which stretches from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan, is located near the Afghan-Pakistan border. The Hindu Kush range is known for its high snow-capped peaks, with the highest point being Tirich Mir at 7708 meters in Pakistan's Chitral District.
Ripon College in Wisconsin had approximately 840 students in 2015, with most of them living on campus.

Fox Sports is a brand name for various sports channels, divisions, and media owned by the Murdoch family. Rupert Murdoch, through his company News Corporation, controlled Fox Sports until the company split in 2013. Now, the Murdoch family owns both 21st Century Fox and News Corp through the Murdoch Family Trust.
Wildfang is a US-based clothing company that designs apparel for women with a tomboyish style.
Bessie Smith was an American blues singer who lived from April 15, 1894 to September 26, 1937.
Speech recognition (SR) is a field of computational linguistics that uses computer science and electrical engineering to translate spoken language into text.
Aleister Crowley was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer. He was born Edward Alexander Crowley on October 12, 1875, and died on December 1, 1947.
Poldark is a British-American drama television series that premiered on BBC One on March 8, 2015.
"Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge" starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol was released on October 20, 1995. Filming took place from September 1994 to August 1995 in India, London, and Switzerland.

Timothy Simon Roth, born May 14, 1961, is an English actor and director. Tim Roth, born December 6, 1975, is the guitarist, backing vocalist, and only remaining founding member of the Canadian metal band Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986 and they had three children together.

Sean Penn is a two-time Academy Award-winning actor. He began his career in the 1980s and gained critical acclaim for his roles in films like *At Close Range*, *State of Grace*, and *Carlito's Way*. He received his first Academy Award nomination for *Dead Man Walking* and won his first Oscar for *Mystic River*. He won his second Oscar for *Milk*. Penn also directed the critically acclaimed film *Into the Wild*.

The Earth's atmosphere was initially formed by volcanic outgassing, but lacked oxygen and was toxic to modern life. As the Earth cooled, a solid crust formed, allowing liquid water to exist on the surface. Plate tectonics continues to shape the Earth's oceans and continents, while human activity now significantly impacts the atmosphere and other systems, including the ozone layer, greenhouse gases, and the quality of air and water. Water covers 71% of the Earth's surface.
Nuuk, also known as GodthaÌb, is the capital and largest city of Greenland and is located in the municipality of Sermersooq.

"How to Train Your Dragon 2" is written and directed by Dean DeBlois. The film features the voices of Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz-Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig, as well as new additions Cate Blanchett, Djimon Hounsou, and Kit Harington.

"Down with Love" is a 2003 romantic comedy film directed by Peyton Reed and starring ReneÌe Zellweger and Ewan McGregor. The film is a parody of the sex comedies popular in the 1950s and 1960s, particularly those starring Doris Day and Rock Hudson. A television series based on the film, "Down with Love," aired in Taiwan in 2010.
Paris Hilton's self-titled album, "Paris," is primarily an electronic dance music album. It also includes elements of reggae, soul, and pop rock.

"Stripes" is a 1981 American comedy film directed by Ivan Reitman and starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P.J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy. The film features several actors in their first significant roles, including John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold. Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton also appeared early in their careers.
Janelle MonaÌe Robinson is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She was born on December 1, 1985, and is signed to her own label, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her song "Love or Lust" featured in the film *Deep Cover*. She also sang choruses for many West Coast rap songs, including Snoop Dogg's "Gin and Juice" and Dr. Dre's "Let Me Ride".

The University of Mississippi has a diverse student body, with 55% of undergraduates and 60% of the overall student population coming from Mississippi. 23% of students are minorities, and international students represent 90 different nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet -- Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.
Johanna Braddy is an actress who has starred in several television series, including "Video Game High School," "Unreal," and "Quantico."

Martin Van Buren was the eighth President of the United States, serving from 1837 to 1841. He was a member of the Democratic Party and held other high-ranking positions, including Vice President and Secretary of State, under President Andrew Jackson. Van Buren was a key supporter of Jackson's 1828 presidential campaign and ran for Governor of New York to help boost Jackson's popularity. After serving as governor for two months, Van Buren resigned to become Jackson's Secretary of State. Following his resignation as Secretary of State, Jackson appointed Van Buren as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey is home to two universities: Rutgers University-Camden, founded in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is the tenth most populous state in the U.S. and the largest state east of the Mississippi River. It is the only state with two peninsulas, making it a popular destination for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionized publishing in the 1930s by selling inexpensive paperbacks through stores like Woolworths. These paperbacks, priced at sixpence, made high-quality fiction and non-fiction accessible to the general public.
The 2008 film "Australia" was filmed in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who helped make country music popular worldwide.  "Excuse My French" is the name of both a debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama. The film, based on Salama's own experiences, was initially deemed too sensitive by the censorship board and Salama was forced to adjust the script while trying to preserve the film's core concept of religious discrimination.
Derek Hough starred in the 2013 dance film *Make Your Move*, which was inspired by the classic play *Romeo and Juliet*. The film was a South Korean-American independent production.

"Bad Romance" is a song by Lady Gaga from her 2009 extended play, *The Fame Monster*. The song was leaked before its official release, but Gaga debuted the final version at Alexander McQueen's Paris Fashion Week show in October 2009. The song was a worldwide success, topping charts in many countries and selling 12 million copies worldwide, making it one of the best-selling singles of all time. There is also a 2011 independent drama film titled *Bad Romance* (French title: *Les Mauvais Romans*).

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including franchises like Shrek, Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, and How to Train Your Dragon. They have also released other popular films like Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. DreamWorks Animation also produced the animated television series Trollhunters for Netflix.

Chris Eubank, born in 1966, is a former British professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Chris Eubank Jr., born in 1989, is also a British professional boxer. Eubank Jr. has held the IBO super-middleweight title since 2017, and has previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.
Sophia Anna Bush is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist, known for her roles in the films *John Tucker Must Die*, *The Hitcher*, and *The Narrows*.

James Murdoch is the CEO of 21st Century Fox and the chairman of Sky plc. He is the son of Rupert Murdoch, the chairman and acting CEO of Fox News and former chairman and CEO of News Corporation, the world's second-largest media conglomerate.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was the second highest earning actress/model in Israel, behind Bar Refaeli, with most of her income coming from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival, often shortened to Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band that was active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are bony growths on the heel bone that are typically detected by an x-ray.
The South Wales Coalfield, located in south Wales, is a large region with abundant coal deposits, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football competition for the top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was originally called the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when it began in 1962.

Mary of Teck became Queen Mother after her husband, George V, died in 1936. Her eldest son, Edward, abdicated the throne to marry Wallis Simpson, causing Mary great distress. She then supported her second son, Albert, who became George VI. Mary died in 1952 during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.
The film "Poseidon" had a budget of $160 million and grossed $181,674,817 worldwide.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first awarded in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton are tied for the most wins with three each.

Human trafficking is the trade of humans for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization estimates that forced labor alone generates $150 billion in profits annually. Of the 21 million people trafficked, 68% are exploited for labor, 22% are sexually exploited, and 10% are exploited in state-imposed forced labor.
The animated film *Rio* was released in 2011 and had a sequel, *Rio 2*, released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I, King of France from 1515-1547, was known as "Francis of the Large Nose" and the "Knight-King" for his involvement in wars against Holy Roman Emperor Charles V.  He was unsuccessful in his wars against Charles V and formed a controversial alliance with the Ottoman Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent.  There was also a conflict between Francis I and Charles V in the Italian War of 1536-1538.  There was also a Holy Roman Emperor named Francis I (Franz Stefan, Francois Etienne) who reigned from 1708-1765, but his wife held the real power.

Peking University (PKU), located in Beijing, is China's first modern national university. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Taixue or Guozijian, and served as China's Ministry of Education. PKU is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his mutton chops, gravelly voice, and unique bass playing style.
Global warming has significant effects on humans, including threats to food security due to decreasing crop yields and the abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.
"Australia" is a 2008 film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman. It is a historical romantic drama film.
Michael Vick is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the NFL, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a wide range of traditions, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices like traditional food and craft making. Folklore also includes oral traditions such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining. They also trained combat cameramen.

James Jones is the name of both an author and a basketball player. James Jones, the author, won the 1952 National Book Award for his first novel, *From Here to Eternity*, which was adapted into a film and later a television series. James Jones, the basketball player, averaged 25 points per game as a senior in high school, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. He has won three NBA championships and finished third in the NBA in three-point percentage during the 2007-2008 season.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema by the American Film Institute in 1999.

Computer animation is the process of creating animated images. The American television series "Trollhunters" is a computer-animated fantasy series created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix. It was produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon resigned from WWE in 2009, with his resignation taking effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in the science fiction series *Doctor Who* from 1974 to 1981. He held the role longer than any other actor. He is also known for narrating the comedy series *Little Britain*. Baker has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach, in the central region of Luxembourg.

Hanford Site is a large, multi-purpose facility that houses a commercial nuclear power plant, the Columbia Generating Station, and various research and development centers, including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official appointed by the President to act as spokesperson for the executive branch, particularly regarding the President, senior executives, and policies. The position is prominent, though not a Cabinet post, due to frequent briefings given to the media, who then inform the public.

Kentucky, nicknamed the "Bluegrass State" due to its fertile soil, is home to the Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky. This region houses two major cities, Louisville and Lexington. Kentucky is also known for its horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston.  Preston also starred in the films The Cat in the Hat, Old Dogs, and Broken Bridges.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper. She is also known by the stylized name Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of the song "Despacito" were released: an electronic version by Major Lazer and MOSKA, and an urban version by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually broadcast via pay-per-view television. In 1987, the WWF scheduled a pay-per-view of their own, Survivor Series, on Thanksgiving night and demanded exclusivity from cable providers on carriage of the event. From 1987, Starrcade was broadcast on pay-per-view, the first NWA event to do so. The WWE Network included the previous Starrcades (1983-1986), which had been transmitted via closed-circuit television, alongside the rest of the Starrcades in the pay-per-view section, and rated the show as TV-MA due to the amount of violence in the matches.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director who works in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise, which ended in 2005. It is the first series developed specifically for the streaming service CBS All Access.

Terry Crews played professional football as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins. He also played in the World League of American Football for Rhein Fire.

"Excuse My French" is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana.  The 2014 Egyptian comedy film "Excuse My French" was directed by Amr Salama and is based on his experiences at a public middle school in Egypt.  British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, known as Plan B or Ben Drew, was born on October 22, 1983.

A floppy disk, also known as a floppy, diskette, or just disk, is a type of disk storage made of a thin, flexible magnetic medium sealed in a rectangular plastic case. The case is lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala experienced political instability and civil strife from the mid-19th century to the late 20th century. From 1960 to 1996, a civil war was fought between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, resulting in the genocide of the Maya population by the military.
Forceps are a handheld, hinged instrument used for grasping and holding objects. They are also known as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The seventh and final season of the television series "The Closer" began on July 11, 2011. The show had finished its sixth season as the highest-rated drama on cable television.

Dr. Jack Shephard is the main character in the television series *Lost*, played by Matthew Fox. The show aired on ABC from 2004 to 2010 and had an average of 16 million viewers per episode in its first season.

Matthew McConaughey is an American actor born on November 4, 1969. Since 2011, he has focused on dramatic roles in films such as *The Lincoln Lawyer*, *Bernie*, *Killer Joe*, *The Paperboy*, *Mud*, *Magic Mike*, *The Wolf of Wall Street*, *Dallas Buyers Club*, *Interstellar*, *The Sea of Trees*, and *Free State of Jones*. *Mud* (2012) stars Matthew McConaughey, Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer, music journalist, record producer, and musician. He is best known for his book *Deep Blues*, his work for the *New York Times* and *Rolling Stone*, and his clarinet playing in the band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer who is best known for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, died in 1941. Gutzon Borglum designed the sculpture and oversaw its construction from 1927 to 1941 with the help of his son, Lincoln. After Gutzon's death, Lincoln took over as leader of the project.

The film "Underdog" is directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. The film stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents from Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teens from a space habitat called "The Ark" who are among the first to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on the teens' parents, including Clarke's mother, Dr. Abby Griffin, and the Chancellor of the Ark, Thelonious Jaha.

The Concert for Bangladesh was a successful humanitarian aid project that raised awareness and funds for refugees in Bangladesh. Despite financial difficulties, it inspired future projects like Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is a highly influential Indian filmmaker who is credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and changing the landscape of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was a statement made by Stephen A. Douglas during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858. The debates were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas, who were running for the United States Senate from Illinois. The debates were widely attended, as the issue of slavery was a major concern for people across the nation.

"Easy A" is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her writing career with the publication of *Interview with the Vampire* in 1976 and continued writing sequels in the 1980s. While her early works received mixed reviews, she gained popularity with critics and readers in the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years until his death in 2002.

Camden, New Jersey is the 12th most populous municipality in the state, with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 census. At the beginning of the 20th century, Camden's population was primarily made up of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film *The Canyons*, which was directed by Paul Schrader. *The Canyons* is an American erotic thriller-drama film.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates were held in seven towns in the state of Illinois.
Homer is credited with writing the Iliad and the Odyssey, two important epic poems in ancient Greek literature. The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, was murdered on February 2, 2013, by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a band formed by Chris Cornell (Soundgarden) and members of Rage Against the Machine: Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk is best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991. As of 2016, he is a member of Prophets of Rage. Rage Against the Machine was formed in 1991 and consists of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle MonaÌe Robinson is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. Her first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, was released in 2010 by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town in Louisiana that serves as the parish seat of East Carroll Parish. The University of Mississippi has a student body that is 55% undergraduate and 60% overall from Mississippi. 23% of the student body are minorities and international students come from 90 nations.
The television series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016. The second season is scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in a variety of political roles in New York, including the State Assembly, Attorney General, and U.S. Senator. He reached the pinnacle of his career as Vice President of the United States.

The Soyuz spacecraft was designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s as part of the Soviet space program. It was originally intended for the Soviet manned lunar programs and replaced the Voskhod spacecraft. The Soyuz has been in service since the 1960s and has been used for both unmanned and manned launches.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine released their fourth studio album, *Renegades*, in 2000.  The band broke up in 2000 after lead singer Zack de la Rocha left the band.  De la Rocha began a solo career while the rest of the band formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell.  Audioslave disbanded in 2007, the same year Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a stock market index that tracks the performance of 30 large and financially stable companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. One of these companies is Tata Motors, which is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is located on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It is the 14th most populous country in the world with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants. Vietnam borders China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced high economic growth and is one of the four remaining one-party socialist states in the world.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was an Indian socialist revolutionary who became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement. He was known for two acts of violence against the British in India and was executed at the age of 23.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 film "Dangal," a biographical sports drama directed by Nitesh Tiwari. "Dangal" is about wrestling and features Aamir Khan.

James VI and I, born June 19, 1566, was King of Scotland from July 24, 1567, and King of England and Ireland from March 24, 1603, until his death on March 27, 1625.  Though Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own governments, James ruled both in a personal union. He advocated for a single parliament for both countries. James faced many challenges with Parliament during his reign in England.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand actress known for her roles in television series such as *Shortland Street*, *Xena: Warrior Princess*, *The Cult*, and *Legend of the Seeker*. She has also appeared in films like *Separation City* and the Australian series *Rake*. Cormack is most recognized for her role as Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama *Wentworth*, which she starred in for four years.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who has starred in several films, including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Lady Gaga's album *Artpop* received mixed reviews but was commercially successful. It debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 chart, selling 258,000 copies in its first week. It was Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the United States and sold 757,000 copies overall. *Artpop* was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, selling 2.3 million copies worldwide.
John Frusciante's last album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers was *Stadium Arcadium*, released in 2006. Frusciante left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher was the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She is considered one of the most influential politicians in British history, but her policies remain controversial.
Michael McKagan is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. In addition to his musical career, McKagan has written weekly columns for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain, with a population of around 800,000. It is also the third largest metropolitan area in Spain, with a population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, or the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain.
Buffy Summers is a character who was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The television series "Make It or Break It" ended after three seasons, with the final episode airing on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a field that uses computer science, linguistics, and electrical engineering to translate spoken language into text. SR is used in a variety of applications, including voice user interfaces, search, data entry, and speech-to-text processing. The field has seen significant advances due to the adoption of deep learning methods by companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 and served as its chairman. The convention was originally called the Golden State Comic Book Convention and was founded by a group of San Diegans including Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee.

Rory McIlroy shot a 67 for the third straight day, moving him to 15 under par and into a tie for second place. He is looking to win his first title since May. McIlroy is currently leading the Race to Dubai by 271 points over Danny Willett.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of Bahrain's main opposition group al-Wefaq, believes that national dialogue is necessary to resolve the country's political crisis. He believes that the government must show its willingness to offer concrete solutions and that the Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, seen as a reformist, should be involved in the dialogue. Salman is critical of the UK government's approach to the crisis, arguing that they need to publicly pressure the Bahraini government for reform. He also calls for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists who have been imprisoned.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and early-music pioneer, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and led the academy for 30 years, during which time they produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was known for his work with leading orchestras worldwide and his influential role in the early-music movement. He was also a respected academic, holding positions at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. His legacy is remembered by colleagues and musicians who credit him with fostering a new generation of musicians and promoting historically informed music.

Homicide rates in Scotland have decreased, with 57 victims recorded in the year ending March 2016, the lowest number since 1976. This is half the number of victims recorded nine years ago. Sharp instruments, primarily knives, were the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides. While most accused individuals had an unknown status for alcohol and drug use, 31% were identified as being under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Despite the decrease in homicides, concerns remain about the increase in violent crime, including attempted murder and serious assault, which rose by 27% in the past year.

Bournemouth lost their game against Sunderland 2-1, making them the first team to lose to Sunderland in the Premier League this season. Bournemouth had many scoring opportunities but were unable to capitalize on them, despite Sunderland playing with 10 men after Steven Pienaar was dismissed.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has defended his country's policy of detaining migrants who arrive by boat, saying it is the only way to prevent deaths at sea. The policy has been criticized by the New York Times as "brutal" and "inhumane." Abbott has also drawn criticism for comparing the Islamic State to the Nazis, saying that the Islamic State is worse because they boast about their evil.

The US has suspended talks with Russia regarding the Syrian ceasefire due to Russia's failure to uphold its commitments. The US blames Russia and the Syrian government for the escalation of attacks against civilians, including the bombing of Aleppo's main trauma hospital. Russia denies involvement in the attack on the aid convoy and accuses the US of failing to fulfill its obligations. Despite the suspension of talks, the US and Russia will continue to discuss counter-terrorism operations in Syria to prevent accidental clashes.

Policy Exchange, a think tank, suggests selling high-value social housing to fund the construction of new social housing. The report claims this could raise Â£4.5 billion annually, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes. The government supports the idea, arguing that councils should use their social housing stock efficiently. Labour opposes the plan, arguing that it would displace low-income families and exacerbate the housing crisis. They propose using a bank bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, the city at the center of a measles epidemic. While laboratory tests confirmed a diagnosis of measles, further tests are needed to determine the cause of death. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash a few days after being discharged. His family said they had no idea how he contracted measles as no close family member has it, including his three-year-old daughter who has been vaccinated.
Vincent Hudson, 54, was charged with a historical offense against a boy under 16. The alleged attack occurred in 2001 and Hudson is scheduled to appear in North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.
Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 in a National League match. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute when Jake Lawlor scored. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute when Wes York scored.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the Bristol football club, will begin work on replacing two stands at the stadium in May. The plan was approved by Bristol City Council in November and will increase the stadium's capacity. The work is an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed.

Cuadrilla, the company behind the fracking tests in Lancashire, has suspended drilling after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is examining the data collected before Cuadrilla decides whether to resume drilling. The BGS has confirmed that the tremor was centered near the drilling site and that fracking can cause earthquakes. The BGS is monitoring the situation as a precaution.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner draped on his bagpipes in April 2015. Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and that the banner was a tribute to the victims, not an attempt to deceive anyone. The Hillsborough Justice Campaign confirmed that Carpenter had permission to display the banner but not to collect funds for the charity. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0. Grant Ward scored the first goal for Ipswich, followed by Luke Varney and Tom Lawrence. QPR had few opportunities to score, with their only real chance coming when Sandro headed a corner against the post. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy was pleased with the win, particularly with the performance of Luke Varney. QPR manager Ian Holloway blamed the second goal for the team's poor performance, but also criticized his defenders for not helping the goalkeeper.

Tom Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, is excited to join the club because of its positive direction and the elite performance environment created by the coaches. Wells had a successful T20 Blast season last year, scoring 373 runs at a strike rate of 138.66.

The Redruth Rugby team, currently fifth in National Two South, defeated third-placed Chinnor 29-12, marking their second consecutive win.  The team's strong performance was attributed to the leadership of Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, particularly their impressive tackling.  Despite the victory, coach  Churcher believes the team has room for improvement and must build upon their recent success to avoid wasting their hard-earned win.

This interactive video, created by the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explores the reasons why consumer buying habits change. The video focuses on the impact of new technologies like the freezer and washing powder, as well as cheaper imports, on the types of products available and popular in the UK. It also examines the shifting ownership and ranking of major UK brands.

Two elderly women in Scotland were tricked by phone scammers claiming to be from BT technical support. The scammers gained remote access to their computers and stole money. Police are warning people to be cautious of cold calls and never give out banking information over the phone.

Featherstone Rovers have hired former Swinton Lions coach, John Duffy, on a one-year contract. Duffy, who has a long playing career, will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy's former assistant, Stuart Littler, has replaced him at Swinton.

A woman was found unconscious on Sker Beach with head injuries and hypothermia. The Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded to the scene. The woman was treated and flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to dedicate a radio frequency for satellite tracking of planes. This will allow for real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world, improving upon the current system which relies on ground-based radars and leaves 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The decision was made in response to the disappearance of MH370 in 2014, which exposed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems. The new system will require aircraft to send their position at least every 15 minutes, or more in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at the age of five, has been found at the age of 18. He was living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez was arrested and charged with tampering with records in Ohio. Authorities suspected Bobby Hernandez of being involved in Julian's disappearance in 2002.

A fire at a waste facility in Duncan Street on March 2nd caused travel delays and prompted the Environment Agency (EA) to suspend Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective August 7th, after determining the company was "broadly compliant" with fire safety regulations. The company has until August 7th to appeal the decision. The fire service had raised concerns about the potential impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment, leading to joint visits with the EA. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

Russia is considering two new bills that would allow for the annexation of territories from neighboring countries. The first bill would allow for the annexation of a territory if its people express a desire to join Russia. The second bill would expedite the process of issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly those who are Russian-speaking. These bills are being considered in response to the current crisis in Ukraine, where pro-Russian sentiment is strong in the Crimea region.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of success in Formula 1, is currently experiencing a period of decline.  The team has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, but their recent performance has been disappointing.  The team's slump began in 2013 with issues in chassis design, and despite improvements in the car, the Honda power unit has been a major obstacle.  McLaren's most successful period was during their partnership with Honda in the 1980s and 1990s, but they have faced several scandals and setbacks since then.  Despite their current struggles, McLaren remains optimistic about the future, believing that their car is among the best and that Honda will improve their engine performance.  The team's success hinges on their ability to overcome these challenges and return to their former glory.

Thomas Baker, 44, was shot and killed in Liverpool on January 27th.  Police believe the three suspects, aged 29 and 32, had been waiting outside the Phoenix Gym for an hour before the shooting.  The suspects fled the scene in a silver VW Polo, which was last seen traveling along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road.  Police are asking anyone who may have seen the shooting or the car to come forward.

This article discusses five ways to enjoy Christmas online, including virtual church services, a fantasy game, nativity videos, and Manga versions of the Bible. The article highlights the use of technology to spread religious messages and connect with communities, particularly during the Christmas season.

A public inquiry is being held to determine whether a proposed motorsports circuit can be built on 250 hectares of common land in Ebbw Vale. The developers have offered 320 hectares of replacement land, but experts disagree on whether the replacement land is of equal value and whether the circuit would damage habitats. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, and the Welsh government will ultimately decide whether the project can proceed.

The Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta reported that over 100 people were detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report and said detainees were tortured with electric shocks and beatings. Chechen Muslim clerics condemned the report as an insult to their faith and called for "retribution" against the journalists. The Chechen leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, denied the allegations and said there were no gay people in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is helping people flee the persecution and plans to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute anyone.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, receives housing benefit payments by placing homeless men in properties. The agency is owned by Samir Patel, who also founded the charity Fresh Start Housing in 2010. Fresh Start Housing refers clients to both Investing Solutions and private landlords. The letting agency makes a profit by placing multiple unrelated tenants in one property and charging housing benefit for each person. This results in a higher total benefit payout than the rent fee passed on to the landlord. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, making the venture highly profitable. The company focuses on housing single homeless men over 35, as they are the group facing the greatest challenges in accessing accommodation. However, tenants have reported living in unsuitable properties with problems such as lack of heating, hot water, rats, and damp. The charity Crisis has criticized the relationship between Investing Solutions and Fresh Start Housing, calling it "a new low".

Great Britain lost their final warm-up game for the Eurobasket qualifying campaign to the Netherlands, 76-71. The Netherlands outscored Great Britain 10-0 in the fourth quarter to secure the win. Coach Joe Prunty was pleased with the performance of Ben Gordon, who scored 13 points, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter. Prunty said the key to the qualifying campaign will be to play hard on both ends of the floor.

The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) will debate whether to allow Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather to use 8oz gloves for their fight on August 16th. The NAC typically requires 10oz gloves for fights at 154 lbs, but allows 8oz gloves for fights between 135lbs and 147lbs if both fighters agree and the NAC feels it is justified. The NAC will make a decision on August 16th.

Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism, is losing its last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Sunday Post. The street was once a bustling hub of activity, with nearly every national newspaper having offices there. However, the rise of television and social media, coupled with the move of newspapers to cheaper, more modern printing technology, led to the decline of Fleet Street. The departure of the Sunday Post's London office marks the end of an era for British journalism.

J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series, was recently the target of online abuse after she donated Â£1 million to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum. She has been called a "traitor" for her political views and has blocked some abusive Twitter users she believes were supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). Despite the abuse, Rowling has also interacted with some SNP supporters and found common ground with them politically.

A study by the University of Edinburgh found that children from deprived backgrounds are more likely to be involved in crime and violence. The study, which tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998, found that children from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action as wealthier children who commit the same crime. They were also five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. The study also found that poverty increases the risk of violence, and that contact with the juvenile justice system inadvertently reproduces the conditions in which violence can flourish. Despite a recent fall in crime rates in Scotland, the study found that crime is still highly concentrated amongst poor people and within poor neighborhoods.

Karl Haugh, 25, was stabbed to death in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee, Ireland. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and remanded in custody. Two other men arrested in connection with the killing were released without charge. Police recovered a knife handle and a blade with blood on it at the scene.

Sinn FÃ©in MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted false accusations about Tom Elliott, a former member of the UDR, on a BBC radio program. The tweet was deleted within an hour and Flanagan apologized, admitting the tweet was untrue. Elliott is seeking compensation for the damage caused by the tweet.

Hawick Knitwear, a company founded in 1874, has seen a surge in demand for its sweaters, both for its own brand and for private label clients. The company has increased production to 9,500 sweaters per week to meet this demand, up from 7,500 last year. This success is attributed to the dedicated staff and the company's strong sales both domestically and internationally.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving after hitting 72-year-old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn with his car. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse for his actions, stating he understands Blackburn was a beloved member of the community and that he has turned her "world upside down."

NATO is conducting an anti-submarine warfare exercise in the North Atlantic, simulating a hunt for a German submarine, U33. The exercise is a response to the growing threat from Russian submarines, which have been increasingly active in the region. The exercise highlights a significant gap in Britain's defenses, as they no longer have any maritime patrol aircraft, which are crucial for anti-submarine warfare. Russia has been heavily investing in its submarine fleet, which is now considered the most advanced in the world. The exercise is a reminder that NATO nations need to work together to counter the threat from Russian submarines.

The violence in South Sudan has caused a humanitarian crisis, with over 340,000 people fleeing to neighboring Uganda, more than any other country this year. The violence has been fueled by ethnic tensions, with the Dinka targeting Equatorians and Nuer. Refugees report widespread killings, rapes, and the targeting of civilians. The violence has spread to the previously peaceful southern Equatoria states, forcing many to flee their homes. Uganda has been generous in its response, providing refugees with land, shelter, and resources, but the influx of refugees is straining the country's resources. The international community is being urged to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence.

On November 12th, 38-year-old boxer,  McKenzie, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall. McKenzie, a former football player, began his boxing career in 2013 and has a record of 8 wins and 1 draw. He is the son of former champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a three-time world champion.

Bridgwater Community Hospital, built in 1813, is being replaced with a new Â£33 million facility. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray, and space for mobile scanners. The new hospital is part of the coalition's Â£330 million investment for new NHS facilities across England. The remaining balance of the project will be paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital is expected to be completed by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Sheffield. The victim was found in or near a black Mercedes he was driving. The shooting occurred during a family celebration, and residents reported hearing a gunshot and seeing relatives rush to help the victim. This incident is one of several shootings that have occurred in Sheffield in recent weeks, though previous incidents were located in the north of the city.

Cyber warfare is being waged in Ukraine, with both pro-Ukrainian and pro-Russian hackers targeting government websites, private communications, and public infrastructure. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have used DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites and have hacked into CCTV systems and network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, a pro-Russian group, has targeted Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and voting systems, aiming to disrupt Ukrainian military plans and discredit the government. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, has published leaked documents from the Kremlin, including emails from a former Russian FSB colonel involved in the conflict in eastern Ukraine.

Several MSPs, including former First Minister Alex Salmond, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, and veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, are stepping down from the Scottish Parliament ahead of the May 5th election. Salmond, in his final speech, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill. McNeil, in his farewell address, warned that Holyrood has things to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will be gathering information from pensioners, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations for improving care. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While Rochira acknowledges the positive impact of high-quality care, she has also received concerns about variations in care quality across Wales. The review aims to ensure that those responsible for care services understand the realities of living in residential care and take action to improve the quality of life for older people.

Harbro Group, a Turriff-based company that manufactures and supplies animal feeds, saw pre-tax profits increase to Â£3.5 million despite a Â£1 million drop in turnover. The company's international sales grew in Europe and new markets. Harbro operates 19 Country Store locations across Scotland, offering a variety of products for farming and rural communities. The company acknowledges the challenging agricultural climate but remains confident in its ability to navigate future challenges, including Brexit.

Police are investigating a murder that occurred in Little Gaddesden, Hertfordshire. A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road. A man in his 80s was also taken to the hospital. Police are searching for 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the murder. They have warned the public not to approach him.
The IMF is likely to downgrade its global growth forecast to below 3.4% due to a weakening global economy. This comes after China's trade figures showed a significant decline in exports.

The new chain ferry in Cowes has experienced numerous problems since its launch on May 14th, including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues.  Cars have also been damaged while using the ferry.  The council has ordered an audit of the project and will offer free crossings until July 2nd to allow for feedback.  The council is also considering compensation for local businesses who have lost revenue due to the ferry's problems.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, has been criticized for its discriminatory job advertisements. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called the agency's ads "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" and is asking them to clarify their hiring practices. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the ads, stating that "looks are important" to their clients. Employment lawyer James Lynas said the ads are "clearly unlawful" and that anyone could complain to the EHRC. He added that an employment tribunal could find the use of phrases such as "beautiful and attractive" to be discriminatory against older women. The EHRC stated that employers are not allowed to discriminate based on age, sexual orientation, marital status, number of children, disability, race, or religion. Ms. Jansen defended the agency's practices, stating that clients have specific requests, such as a "Jackie O" look for a personal assistant or a blonde, blue-eyed, Greek woman for a businessman.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, shot and killed 18-year-old Gautami and injured another student, Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and remanded until April 12th. While gun crime is rare in India, there have been other incidents, such as the 2007 shooting of a 14-year-old schoolboy in Delhi.

Glaad's "Where We Are on TV" study found that there were 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters on television between June 2016 and May 2017. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16, but over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced he will not seek re-election. This decision comes after a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The decision follows a police investigation into "alleged financial irregularities" surrounding a Â£10.25 million loan from the borough council to Northampton Town FC, which Mackintosh authorized when he was leader. The loan was intended to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land, but the money is now missing and the stand remains half built.

Roy Oliver, a former police officer in Balch Springs, Texas, was indicted for murder in the death of 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. The shooting occurred in April when police responded to a house party. Oliver fired into a car full of teenagers as they left the party, killing Edwards. The initial police report claimed the car reversed aggressively towards the officer, but video footage showed the car driving forward. Oliver was also charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon for the other teenagers in the car. If convicted, Oliver would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

Melania Trump has decided to stay in New York with Barron until he finishes the school year, making her one of only three First Ladies in history to not live in the White House during their husband's presidency. While some have criticized her decision, others have defended it, saying it is a responsible choice for a parent. The article goes on to discuss how other First Ladies have handled their roles and families, including Frances Folsom Cleveland, who lived in a separate house during her husband's presidency, and Dolley Madison, who sent her son away to school.
