The article also notes that Chelsea Clinton and Malia and Sasha Obama lived in the White House during their fathers' presidencies, and that the Obamas made a conscious effort to maintain a normal family life despite their unique circumstances.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on October 27th. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is investigating the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation and awaits the findings.

The Met Office issued a yellow warning for strong winds, with gusts up to 75 mph expected, particularly west of the mountains. The unusual easterly direction of the wind could exacerbate its impact. Travel disruptions on roads and at sea are likely. The affected counties include Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A fallen tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, caused by overnight gusts, closed Telford Road, a main route into the town. The road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for cleanup.

The Nottingham Panthers and the Sheffield Giants played a close game, with the Giants winning 4-3. The Giants were short-handed for the first period, but Jeff Dimmen tied the game for the Panthers. Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal to put the Giants ahead, but Andy Bohmback tied the game again. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored for the Giants, while David Ling scored for the Panthers. The teams will play again on Saturday night. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

Lewis Hamilton started the race in last place and suffered a broken front wing on the first lap. He had to make five pit stops and is now 36 points behind Nico Rosberg in the championship standings. Sebastian Vettel finished second, but collided with his teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. Raikkonen recovered to finish fifth. Nico Rosberg won the race after taking the lead from Daniel Ricciardo on lap three.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, came out as gay in an interview with Die Zeit. His announcement was praised by many, including former teammates, football administrators, and politicians. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, which has struggled with homophobia in football. The announcement has sparked hope that it will lead to greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Midfielder,  Liam Sidwell, has played 32 games for Brighton this season, helping them achieve promotion to the Premier League.  Sidwell is hoping to sign a new contract with Brighton and play in the Premier League again. He believes he has earned a new contract with his performance this season.

Blackpool and Colchester United tied 1-1. Colchester took the lead in the 12th minute when Jamille Matt scored. Blackpool equalized in the 17th minute after a goalmouth scramble. Blackpool had a chance to win in the 75th minute but Tom Aldred headed wide. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

Colchester United signed 29-year-old defender, Luke Reid, who previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Reid could make his debut for the U's in their EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester lost their first game of the season to Accrington 3-1.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising Â£1.5 million to build a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in honor of the more than 1,400 officers and staff who have died in the line of duty over the past 250 years. The memorial will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out for the families of fallen officers, with the names of loved ones inscribed as a personal memorial. The government has committed Â£1 million towards the Â£4 million needed for the memorial, which is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United won their match against Sunderland 1-0, extending their lead at the top of the table to 15 points with eight games remaining. Manager Alex Ferguson stated that the team is focused on the games ahead, not the past, and that they will be going into the derby against Manchester City with a 15-point lead. Ferguson will make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea due to injuries sustained by Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea. He also mentioned that Wayne Rooney was tired after returning from international duty and that Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez will be available for the match.

Google paid Â£10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, which Google CEO Eric Schmidt claims is the legally required amount. Schmidt believes that the government should change the tax system if they want companies to pay more taxes.  Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggests a new committee be established to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, allowing them to hear evidence from companies in secret. Google, along with other multinationals, has been criticized for minimizing their UK tax payments by routing sales through Ireland.  Schmidt has previously argued that corporate taxes should be levied where companies conduct economic activity and take risks, rather than where products are consumed. He has also called for a debate on international tax reform.

The NHS is trying to reduce its reliance on agency staff, which cost the service Â£3.6 billion last year. A cap was introduced in October that has saved Â£600 million, but the NHS is still Â£1 billion short of its goal. The regulator, NHS Improvement, is publishing league tables of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending and collecting information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust.

Longford Town Centre, once a thriving commercial hub, is now a symbol of Ireland's economic downturn. However, local businesses are seeing signs of improvement. Matt O'Brien, a local shopkeeper, has seen an increase in business and has expanded his offerings to include children's wear and dress hire. Despite this, the opposition party, Fianna FÃÂ¡il, criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, arguing that investments should be directed towards broadband improvement rather than water meters. The government, however, points to the Center Parcs development in Ballymahon, which is expected to create 1,000 jobs upon its opening in 2019. While the project is still pending planning permission, local officials are optimistic about its success. Despite the positive developments, local businesses like O'Brien's believe more can be done to boost the economy, such as offering free parking. Overall, the midlands is experiencing the beginnings of an economic recovery, but more needs to be done to support local businesses and attract investment.

The tournament features eight teams competing against each other twice, with the top four advancing to the playoffs. The competition concludes on May 29th in the same stadium.  You can follow scores, fixtures, and results on BBC Sport.

The number of plastic bags used in England has increased by 200 million since 2013.  To combat this environmental issue, England will begin charging 5p for plastic bags in October. This follows the lead of Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where charging for bags has resulted in a decrease in their use. Campaigners hope the charge will encourage people to reuse bags and reduce the number of bags ending up in landfills and waterways.

Strong winds across Wales caused damage to a school roof, power outages for hundreds of homes, train delays, and road closures. The winds also forced the cancellation of ferry services and the closure of some tourist attractions. While the winds eased into Friday evening, a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of a Boxing Day event.

Michael B. Jordan will star in the upcoming Marvel film *Black Panther*, alongside Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. The film will be directed by Ryan Coogler, who also directed Jordan in *Creed*. *Black Panther* is set to be released in February 2018.

Alexandra Palace's east wing is undergoing a Â£26.6 million restoration project to transform it into a cultural destination. The project includes the restoration of the theatre, which will be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired and refurbished. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing Â£18.8 million, Haringey Council is contributing Â£6.8 million, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust is committed to raising the final Â£1 million by summer 2017. The theatre, which has been unused for decades, still has much of its original decor and stage machinery.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after 61 caps for England. He made his senior debut in 2009 and was a member of two World Cup and two European Championship squads. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps and scored his only international goal in a 2014 World Cup qualifier against Moldova.

A fire destroyed the Smith family's home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador. The fire was started by rubbish burned in the wood stove, and the fire alarm did not go off. The family escaped with only their pajamas, but their pets did not survive. The community has rallied to support the family with donations of clothes, shoes, and a bike for the son, David, who woke his mother and sister and saved their lives.

Energy drink giant Red Bull is considering a Â£200m offer for West Ham, which was bought by Sullivan and Gold in 2010 for Â£105m. They now own over 85% of the club, which has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan has said that a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold intend to pass ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards were held in Los Angeles, where "The Fault in Our Stars" won best movie and Shailene Woodley won best female performance. Other winners included Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, and Jennifer Lopez. Kevin Hart won the comedic genius award and Robert Downey Jr. won the Generation Award. The ceremony also included previews of upcoming films such as "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and "Ultron."

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old forward, has been loaned from Aberdeen to St Mirren. Smith has scored five goals for Dundee United this season and has made 89 appearances for Aberdeen. St Mirren manager Jack Ross believes Smith will be a good addition to the team and will provide another attacking option.

Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to repair 145 potholes per day for the next four months. The council will also have extra staff repairing drainage systems and clearing debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework on EnQuest's Thistle platform. The exposure was less than 1% of the level reportable to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), but EnQuest notified the HSE. EnQuest and Wood Group have stated that they are committed to employee safety and have taken additional precautionary steps to prevent future exposure. The workers, however, are concerned about potential long-term health effects and are undergoing blood tests. The Unite union believes the workers have been poorly treated and that there should be more transparency about safety incidents. The HSE has been made aware of the incident but did not investigate because it was not reportable under current regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) in Singapore is returning a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India after it was determined the artwork was likely stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. The sculpture was purchased from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007, but the company's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The ACM will pursue legal action to recover the $650,000 purchase price.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. The quake was felt as far away as Milan and Florence, causing buildings to shake and people to evacuate into the streets. While there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, phone lines and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution and will be checked for damage. This is the latest in a series of earthquakes in the area, including two in May that left over 20 people dead.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, has successfully grown a banana plant in South Yorkshire, despite initial doubts about the climate's suitability. The banana is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar has delayed the release of Grand Theft Auto V until March 24th, citing the need for additional testing and polishing. The company has also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release date. The PC version of GTA V will feature 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor configurations. Minimum PC specifications for the game have also been released.

The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards. The 76-year-old artist,  David Simpson, won the Â£25,000 prize for his painting "Squint (19)" at the Walker Art Gallery in Liverpool. Simpson, who was previously shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, said winning was "very nice indeed". Judge Ansel Krut described "Squint (19)" as "quite extraordinary" and "a little bit like a tone poem" that "gradually starts to build a picture". The painting depicts a leper squint, which Simpson described as "holes made in the sides of medieval churches so the undesirables could look through to the service and somehow take part". Simpson plans to use the prize money to purchase "stretches, canvas and - particularly - good quality paints".

The offices of two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked early Thursday morning. Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building, causing a fire that was quickly extinguished by firefighters. Windows were shattered by gunfire at both buildings, which are located 20km apart. Police are investigating the attacks and searching for the assailants. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

The 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, will join the Mariners on a free transfer on January 1st. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. This is the first signing for the Mariners under manager Marcus Bignot.

Arsene Wenger, manager of Arsenal, commented on the possibility of Gareth Southgate becoming the permanent manager of the England national team. Wenger believes Southgate has the experience and observation skills to be successful, but that he needs to prove himself through his decisions. Wenger also stated that Arsenal is working to extend the contract of defender Hector Bellerin, who has been linked with a move to Barcelona or Manchester City. Finally, Wenger confirmed that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are investigating the incident with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is cooperating fully.

The Scottish government has reached an agreement with Serco Northlink to end a dispute over the pay of seafarers on two freight boats serving the Northern Isles. The new charter arrangement will see contracted out services return to Serco Northlink, ensuring that all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage. The agreement comes after a long-running dispute with Seatruck, the previous operator, who argued that the national minimum wage did not apply to the crew.

Jamie Mitchell was found guilty of manslaughter after he intervened in an argument between his mother and her boyfriend, Ken Dickie, who later died. Mitchell admitted to assaulting Dickie during the fight and later lied to police about the events, attempting to pervert the course of justice. Mitchell and his mother will be sentenced on February 6th.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter known for his work with Michael Jackson and Heatwave, died at the age of 66 after a battle with cancer. Temperton, nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, was born in Cleethorpes, North East Lincolnshire, and began writing songs after listening to Radio Luxembourg as a child. He started his career as a keyboardist for the disco group Heatwave, writing hits like "Boogie Nights," "Always & Forever," and "Groove Line." Temperton's work caught the attention of producer Quincy Jones, who hired him to write songs for Michael Jackson's "Off the Wall" and "Thriller" albums. Temperton's songs for Jackson, including "Rock With You," "Thriller," and "Baby Be Mine," helped make "Thriller" the best-selling album of all time in the US. Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 for his work on "Birdland" and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986 for his work on the soundtrack for "The Color Purple."

A team of researchers from Swansea University, Exeter, Reading, and Brazil discovered over 450 ancient earthworks, or geoglyphs, in the western Brazilian Amazon. These structures, possibly 2,000 years old, are thought to have been used sporadically for ritual gatherings, similar to Stonehenge or Mayan pyramids. The researchers found evidence that the surrounding vegetation was taller than the geoglyphs, suggesting they were not visible from above the forest canopy. This discovery challenges the previous assumption that the Amazonian forests were untouched by humans before the arrival of Europeans. The team found evidence of human-induced biodiversity in the region, suggesting that ancient people practiced "agroforestry" by concentrating on economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. This practice may have contributed to the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests today.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey in straight sets at the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios, who won the Japan Open on Sunday, said he was tired from traveling and attributed his quiet demeanor on the court to fatigue. He also mentioned that the long ride to the courts was not ideal. Last year, Kyrgios was fined for using foul language at the Shanghai Masters.

The HPV vaccine, currently given to girls aged 12-13 to prevent cervical cancer, is being advocated for by scientists and charities to also protect against head and neck cancers. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision on expanding the vaccination program to include boys.  Charities and organizations are urging the Welsh government to take action, citing the increasing number of head and neck cancer cases, particularly among younger men.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy battling gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away after a courageous fight against cancer. He documented his journey on social media, inspiring many with his positive attitude. Despite his illness, Jak attended his school prom for 10 minutes, receiving support from former Rangers players. He was visited by players from various Scottish teams and the cast of Wicked. After learning his cancer had spread, Jak and his family focused on making the most of his remaining time, enjoying experiences like a romantic dinner, a party with former Rangers players, and a ride in a supercar.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a match that saw few chances for either side. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside in the first half, and Egypt's Mohamed Salah set up Abdallah El Said for the winning goal in the 89th minute. The win means Egypt will play Ghana on Wednesday with top spot of Group D still at stake, while Uganda is out of the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has chosen the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College as the preferred location for a new railway station in Skelmersdale. The decision was made after a comparative study by Network Rail of several potential sites. The council plans to work with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The chosen location is large enough for future expansion and has good access to the town and surrounding area. The council will now begin the process of acquiring the land.
Police discovered a large-scale marijuana grow operation in a warehouse near Ashbourne and arrested a man in his late 40s.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was found injured in Hamelin, Germany, after being dragged through the streets by the neck. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender, turned himself in to authorities. The woman underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. The motive for the attack is still under investigation.

A study of 4,600 Australian workers found that women are just as likely as men to ask for a pay raise, but are less likely to receive one. The study debunked the theory that women are reluctant to ask for more money, finding no evidence to support this claim.  The study found that men were 25% more likely to receive a pay raise when they asked, even when comparing full-time workers to full-time workers and part-time workers to part-time workers. The researchers believe that this difference is likely due to discrimination against women. The study also found that women and men under 40 are negotiating pay and conditions at the same rate, suggesting that negotiating behavior may be changing.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years, but has not found a suitable location. The two remaining cemeteries are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council has investigated many sites, but they have all been discounted due to factors such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or restrictive covenants.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, will feature an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online information from signs and posters on the festival grounds. The app will provide videos, band interviews, and other content that can be viewed on phones and tablets. The app will also allow people around the world to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," a rare occurrence that can happen to horses with no underlying health issues. While Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, including overheating and "wobbling," he had never collapsed before and showed no signs of ataxia on the day of his death. Despite the rarity of such incidents, the BHA is committed to understanding the causes and preventing them.

The Serbian tennis duo of Novak Djokovic and Nenad Zimonjic lost their doubles match at the Rio Olympics to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares. This loss came after Djokovic was defeated in the singles competition by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, the world's number one tennis player, had previously lost in the third round of Wimbledon to American Sam Querrey. He then went on to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The annual chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Scotland, will feature over 20 competitors from various countries. The competitors will use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will be returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Gareth Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, is recovering from a foot injury sustained in September. He is aiming to return to play in February, in time for the Six Nations tournament. Webb has renewed his contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from other teams to stay with his home region.

On Tuesday morning, two men were apprehended by US border agents near Sumas, Washington while attempting to smuggle 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One of the men fired at the agents and fled, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was immediately taken into custody. The fugitive, Nathan Hall, was later arrested in British Columbia.  Kali Henifin and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for their alleged roles in the smuggling operation. Henifin was accused of planning to pick up the men at the border, while Lambert was to be paid $11,000 to drive the drugs to San Francisco. The three defendants in US custody face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, with over 4,500 children counseled in the past year compared to 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity warns that online trolls cause misery and humiliation for thousands of children, and that cyberbullying can follow children home, making it difficult to escape. Childline president Dame Esther Rantzen urges adults, parents, and teachers to intervene to protect children from online bullying, as it often gets worse if left unchecked. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, during which the Anti Bullying Alliance will work with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the problem.

The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. This angered Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the US of helping draft the resolution. In response, Israel recalled its ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in settlements, citing a desire to avoid further straining relations with the US ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said the resolution "paves the way" for the upcoming conference on Middle East peace in France.

Prince William, in a BBC interview, praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch on the eve of her 90th birthday. He also addressed recent criticism of his work ethic, stating that he takes his duties seriously but is finding his own way. The Queen celebrated her birthday with a series of events, including a visit to the Royal Mail delivery office and a ceremony to open a new bandstand. Ten stamps were released to mark the occasion, featuring four generations of the Royal Family. The Queen will also light a beacon on Thursday evening, setting off a chain of beacons across the UK and around the world.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored two quick goals in the first half to give West Ham the lead. Cheltenham had a few chances to score, but West Ham goalkeeper Adrian was able to keep them at bay. West Ham made seven changes to their lineup after losing to Manchester United and Southampton in the Premier League. Cheltenham was unchanged from their 3-0 loss to Carlisle in the league. This was the second time the two teams had met, with West Ham winning the previous match 2-1 in 2013.

A German tourist, Andreas Werner, was fined Â£1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years after pleading guilty to causing the death of a motorcyclist, Aidan McNicholl, in a crash. The victim's family did not want Werner to be sent to jail, accepting that the crash was a momentary lapse in concentration.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist, returned to the UK after fighting in Syria. He was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, and was involved in propaganda videos and appeals for donations. Khawaja faked his own death and attempted to sneak back into Britain, but was apprehended by police. He is considered a dangerous man and is facing a possible life sentence for his role in the Syrian conflict.
Barnsley signed 22-year-old Kayden Jackson from Wrexham. Jackson scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham. He is Barnsley's third signing for next season.

A container of Vanish laundry detergent bottles was lost overboard from a ship near Land's End in May. The bottles have been washing up on beaches in Cornwall, including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion. The National Trust is clearing the bottles from the beaches as they pose a risk to wildlife. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency has not confirmed that the bottles are from the lost container, but the National Trust believes that is the case. Cornwall Wildlife Trust is concerned about the impact of the detergent on marine life. Cornwall Council is monitoring the beaches and advising the public to keep children and dogs away from the bottles.

A car crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at 2 pm. Several people sustained minor injuries, and the road was closed with diversions in place. Police Scotland is investigating the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a French center-back, signed a new contract with Bolton after helping them secure promotion to the Championship. Dervite joined Bolton in 2014 and made 83 appearances for the club. He made 14 appearances last season, contributing to Bolton's second-place finish in League One.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour have worked together in the House of Lords to defeat the government on issues such as EU citizens' rights and Brexit. However, their alliance has broken down over the issue of Brexit, with the Lib Dems pushing for amendments to the Brexit deal and Labour deferring to the House of Commons. The Lib Dems accuse Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and "lining up with the Conservatives", while Labour accuses the Lib Dems of "grandstanding" and giving people "false hope". Despite this recent disagreement, both parties have a history of working together on other issues, and the Lib Dems are open to future collaboration. However, a Labour source predicts "residual tensions" and doubts that the two parties will be working together closely in the future.

The UK is facing a difficult decision regarding its defense spending. While the world is becoming more dangerous, the UK has been making significant cuts to its armed forces. The size of the UK's regular army is being reduced, the Royal Navy has a fleet of just 19 warships, and the RAF has been left with only eight front-line fast jet squadrons. The UK has also fallen to sixth place in the world for defense spending, behind the US, China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, and France. The UK is likely to fall below the NATO threshold of 2% of GDP spent on defense, and the military top brass are worried about further cuts. The Conservatives and UKIP are committed to renewing Britain's nuclear deterrent, while Labour would continue the round-the-clock patrols but with three rather than four submarines. The Liberal Democrats would retain a nuclear deterrent but end CASD, while the SNP and Greens would scrap it altogether. The UK will have two new operational aircraft carriers by the end of the decade, but there is a danger that they will be more like the emperor's new clothes, as the Royal Navy will struggle to crew both carriers.

Barcelona paid Â£48.6 million for Neymar, but the total cost of the player, including signing-on fees, wages, agents fees, and taxes, is Â£106.8 million. The club has been investigated for misappropriating funds during the transfer, but they have denied any wrongdoing and have made a complimentary tax declaration of â¬13,550,830.56 to cover any potential discrepancies.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father, was killed in a car crash when a car driven the wrong way on the motorway hit the van he was riding in. The driver of the other car, Albert Kenneth Newman, also died. Luciw's family and the driver of the van, Andy Harrington, believe that older drivers should be required to undergo regular driving tests and medical examinations to ensure their safety on the road. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) maintains that there is no evidence that older drivers are more likely to cause accidents than other drivers and that they have no plans to restrict licensing based on age.

An independent review of transvaginal mesh implants concluded that the procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse. The report recommended that patients be offered a range of treatments and given the information to make informed choices. The report also said reporting of adverse events should be mandatory. The review was controversial, with two patients quitting the review group in protest at what they said was a watered-down report. The chairwoman of the independent review apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the review's final report. An independent expert will now examine the process by which the report came to its conclusions.

Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British 5,000m record by 14 seconds, running 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially questioned whether the race met all the criteria for a record-breaking attempt, as Muir was the only competitor running the 5,000m. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time is expected to be ratified as an official record. McColgan believes Muir has the potential to win world medals and that her record-breaking race was similar to her own 25 years ago, where she also ran alone and lapped other runners.

The passage describes the results of the Olympic equestrian event, where Michael Jung won gold aboard Sam.  France's Astier Nicolas took silver and American Phillip Dutton won bronze.  GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, despite a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase.  Fox-Pitt had led after the dressage phase, but dropped to 21st after incurring several time penalties in the cross country.  Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Andy Murray won his third round Wimbledon match against Fabio Fognini in four sets, 6-2 4-6 6-1 7-5. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Murray won despite Fognini having five set points to force a fifth set. Murray was able to win five games in a row to seal the victory.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was closed for three months after being found to have served alcohol past licensing hours. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was fined Â£3,000 and James Thomas was fined Â£1,000 for allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge stated that O'Neill had an "appalling record" and that the case was "as bad as I have come across".

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched his party's manifesto, "Real Partnership," which calls for action on issues such as tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, and standing up for the LGBT community. Nesbitt believes the election should be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle and the DUP's handling of it. He has stated that he would prefer to form a government with the SDLP rather than Sinn FÃÂ©in. Nesbitt has faced criticism for his comments about transferring to the SDLP, but he maintains that he has no regrets and is confident in his position.

Northern Ireland will introduce a motion to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses, mirroring similar legislation in England and Wales. This motion, dubbed "Turing's Law," will allow for both posthumous pardons and applications for pardons by living men convicted of such offenses. The motion will be presented to the assembly for approval and is expected to contain the same provisions as the English and Welsh legislation.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, broke the Scottish 1500m record with a time of 4:19.12, placing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This time also placed her second on the British all-time list. Muir is pleased with her performance and hopes to secure a spot on the Great Britain Olympic team in Rio. She is currently training for the British trials in Birmingham from June 24-26.
The passage lists pictures of 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as having the "most excellent" water quality.

The inquiry into the death of Alexander Litvinenko concluded that the Russian state was likely responsible for his murder. Litvinenko, a former Russian intelligence officer, was poisoned with polonium-210 in 2006 after meeting with two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. While the inquiry did not find evidence that Russian President Vladimir Putin was involved, it did state that Litvinenko's defection to the UK and his criticisms of Putin could have been seen as acts of treachery. The inquiry also noted that the suspects left a trail of polonium behind them and had no credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them.

Steve Smith, 26, has been named the new captain of the Australian cricket team, replacing Michael Clarke who has retired. Smith has previously captained the team in three Tests against India and has a strong record with 2,952 runs in 32 Tests. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Both will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

Tim Farron, the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, refused to answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin. He stated that he is passionate about LGBT+ rights and that defending equal marriage is a top priority. He also wants to extend marital rights for transgender people. Farron voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 because of concerns about "protection of individual liberties." He supports equal access under law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

Accord Healthcare will be using the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015, for its pharmaceutical production. The company hopes to hire many of the former Sanofi employees, and the investment is expected to have a positive impact on the local economy.

Three senior staff members are leaving Aberdeen City Council: Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland. Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, while Monaghan and Sutherland are taking voluntary redundancy and early retirement. The opposition SNP group leader, Stephen Flynn, believes these departures are a sign of the council's inability to retain senior staff and expects more departures in the future.

After crashing at this year's TT, motorcycle racer Michael Martin has decided to stop racing on Honda motorcycles for the rest of the year. He will not be racing at the North West 200 or the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin says he is not giving up racing altogether, but will focus on classic and unusual races.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). This is the PDP's biggest loss since the end of military rule in 1999, as they also lost the presidential election last month. The APC's victory was particularly strong in the north, including key states like Katsina and Kaduna. However, the PDP managed to hold onto Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships in the south-east. The APC's success has relegated the PDP to a regional party, raising concerns for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari as militant groups could disrupt oil production in the five oil-producing states where the APC failed to win. Despite some violence, the elections were generally more peaceful than in previous years, suggesting a maturing democracy in Nigeria. The PDP will need to rebuild under a new leader after 16 years in power, facing accusations of corruption and failing to address the Islamist insurgency in the north-east.
A restaurant in the UK began serving "puppy platters" after a new law was passed allowing dogs to eat at restaurants, as long as they are outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is questionable to play due to a knee injury. David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing the last game. Jacob Butterfield is hoping to play after scoring a goal in the last game.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the site. The ban was imposed in 2012 after the film "Innocence of Muslims" was uploaded to YouTube, sparking protests in Pakistan. The Pakistani government will be able to request the removal of content from YouTube, but Google has stated that these requests will not be automatically granted.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is being asked to step down because he shares the same nationality as one of the five presidential candidates. Musa Bility, head of the Liberian Football Association, says he will take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. Bility argues that Scala should step down because he did so in the 2015 election when he shared a nationality with the incumbent president. Scala's spokesperson, Andreas Bantel, says there is no conflict of interest because there is no incumbent president in this election. Bility wants to know why the same process is not being followed in this election. The election will take place on February 26th in Zurich, Switzerland.

Two men, Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56), were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday morning while working in a paint-spraying area. Police believe a flashover explosion, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, led to the fire-ball effect that killed the men. The Health and Safety Executive is investigating the incident.

Tunisia and Morocco were both in danger of being banned from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was threatened with expulsion after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (CAF) regarding a controversial penalty call in the 2015 tournament. Morocco was banned from the 2015 tournament after refusing to host it due to concerns about the Ebola virus. However, the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced the fine imposed on Morocco. Both countries have since apologized to CAF and are now preparing to compete in the 2017 tournament.

Following a brawl in the 95th minute of the game, Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho of Manchester City were both given red cards. Aguero was banned for four matches for violent conduct, while Fernandinho was banned for three. Both clubs have until December 8th to respond to the charges.

England won the second test match against Pakistan by a large margin, leveling the series. Joe Root was named man of the match for his impressive performance, scoring 254 runs in the first innings and 71 in the second. England's strong batting and bowling performance overwhelmed Pakistan, who struggled to score runs and were bowled out for 234 in the second innings. The series is expected to be close, with the third test match starting on August 3rd.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and has named Rob Howley as part of his backroom team.  McBryde will be the head coach for the third time, having led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. The WRU believes that the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team.

Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. Southampton took an early lead with a penalty goal by Charlie Austin, but Hull came back in the second half with goals from Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson. Hull's win was aided by the return of Snodgrass, who had been injured, and the strong performance of goalkeeper David Marshall. Southampton manager Claude Puel said his team lacked concentration and that they need to learn from this loss.

A fatal motorcycle crash occurred on the B1191 near Woodhall Spa at approximately 2:15 PM. The motorcyclist, a local resident, was killed, while the tractor driver was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police are requesting witnesses to come forward and the B1191 is closed in both directions between the B1192 and A158 junctions.

Macedonia's President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, saying he wanted to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. The move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, who said it put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. The crisis was sparked by covert recordings which appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has been releasing a steady stream of recordings since February 2015, accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 people, including politicians, journalists and religious leaders. The government denies the accusations, and in return has accused Mr Zaev of trying to "destabilise" the Balkan nation.

Swansea City manager Bob Bradley was sacked and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of the team for the upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club is looking to appoint a new manager quickly, with former Derby manager Paul Clement being the first choice. Curtis, a former player and current assistant manager, believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 and that the team has not been able to adequately replace the players they have lost. He believes the current squad is good enough to stay up and reminds new players of the club's history and how important it is to stay in the Premier League.

Dagenham & Redbridge were relegated from League Two to the National League after losing to Leyton Orient. Dagenham's manager, John Still, said that his team lacked organization and discipline, which led to their defeat. Leyton Orient's interim manager, Andy Hessenthaler, said that the team needed to win games to make the playoffs.

Steven Gerrard, former captain of Liverpool, will return to the club in February as a youth coach. This will be his first job since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Gerrard is working towards his Uefa A coaching licence and hopes to become a manager in the future.
Morton defeated Alloa 4-1. McManus scored two goals for Morton, while Forbes and Johnstone each scored one. McAusland scored the lone goal for Alloa.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three places in Birmingham which have now closed. The owners of these places are being investigated under suspicion of running an illegal school. Ofsted and ministers are concerned that some places are taking advantage of the legal right to home educate to operate what are in fact illegal schools. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors whose job will be to investigate illegal schools. The education secretary has now said she intends to go further and has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools it has identified.

Lilliard Gin, the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837, is located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. The gin is made with local botanicals and aims to capture the "terroir" of the Teviot Valley. The distillery is small, but the team hopes to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence." The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

Gary Green, 51, was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for reversing a tractor into Harry Whitlam, killing him. Green was over twice the legal driving limit at the time of the accident, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer. The accident occurred on private land, so Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan striker, was banned from all football-related activities for biting Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) ruled that the ban was excessive and allowed Suarez to train and play in friendly matches. However, he still has to serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games. Suarez's lawyers argued that FIFA's punishment was too harsh, while Fifpro, the world players' union, was disappointed that the CAS did not reduce the length of the ban. Suarez's competitive debut for Barcelona is likely to be against Real Madrid on October 26th.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a competition in which couples race while one partner carries the other. The race involves a 380-meter course with obstacles such as haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. Blake-Smith and Anna will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

The DVLA will be transitioning to an electronic system for car tax in October 2014, eliminating the need for paper tax discs. This change will likely result in a reduction in the number of refunds processed, leading to changes in job roles at the DVLA. The government plans to manage any job losses through redeployment to other areas of the agency.

Hungary's government has passed laws that restrict asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education, including the Central European University. The EU has criticized these laws, but Hungary's foreign minister stated that Hungary will not back down and that Poland will veto any EU sanctions.

The live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast will be released on March 17, 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will play Gaston. The film will also star Kevin Kline as Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts. Bill Condon will direct the film, which will begin filming in May.

Adrian Gill, a well-known journalist for the Sunday Times, passed away after a battle with cancer. Gill was known for his witty and fearless writing style, and his columns often caused controversy. He was a controversialist but also a kind man and a brilliant writer. Gill began his writing career in the 1980s with art reviews for magazines, before writing for Tatler and then the Sunday Times. He was married twice and had four children.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked by a Russian diplomat in Ulan Bator. The diplomat reportedly hit Sukhbaatar over the head with a bottle and kicked him in the face, putting him in a coma for 10 days. The attack occurred after Sukhbaatar performed on stage wearing a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika, a symbol that predates Hitler and is not considered a hate symbol in Mongolia. The Russian embassy denied the reports, claiming they were distorted, but is investigating the incident. The Mongolian police are also investigating the case, but the suspect has not been arrested due to the severity of the injuries.

On Monday, members of Plane Stupid staged a protest on the northern runway at Heathrow Airport. The protesters were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area. The Metropolitan Police will review airport security.

Glamorgan's Nick Selman scored a century, his second in first-class cricket, to lead his team to a total of 220.  Gloucestershire struggled against the Glamorgan bowlers, with Matt Taylor and Craig Miles taking wickets at regular intervals.  Selman's century was a welcome return to form after a string of low scores.  The day ended with the match evenly balanced.  Glamorgan is being led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after he threatened to ambush police officers on the Dee Estuary. Hughes admitted to making two false reports to the police while intoxicated, with the intention of having officers come to the scene so he could shoot them. Hughes has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was on bail awaiting trial for firearms offences at the time of the threats. He will be sentenced next week.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire in a T20 Blast match, winning by 19 runs. Surrey posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Foakes scoring 90 runs each. Yorkshire's run chase was hindered by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, who dismissed Bairstow, Ballance, and Leaning. Despite Bresnan's 68 runs, Yorkshire was all out for 236. Surrey's captain, Gareth Batty, praised Davies and Foakes' partnership, while Yorkshire's captain, Alex Lees, expressed disappointment with their performance.

A 56ft trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 7:00 am BST reporting a pump failure that was unable to handle incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew towed the vessel to Holyhead after placing a pump on board.

Scottish runner Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, says she is "gutted" to miss the event but is focused on completing her degree. She is considering competing in the World Indoor Championships in March and is looking forward to future Olympic opportunities.

East Ayrshire Council plans to build a new educational campus in Kilmarnock, which will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The council plans to name the campus after renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was a prolific writer, known for his "Laidlaw trilogy" and other Glasgow-based works. He was also a poet, journalist, and broadcaster.

A sea mine was discovered in the river near Gourock, Scotland. As a precaution, three streets were evacuated and residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors. An exclusion zone was also put in place on the river and at sea. The mine, believed to be British and dating back to the 1940s or 1950s, was deemed too unstable to be dealt with in place and will be moved to a safer location.

The UK Sport has allocated Â£345 million to 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo 2020 Games, which is Â£2 million less than the record Â£347 million allocated for the Rio Games. The funding decisions were made to prioritize medal potential and ensure the success of Team GB in Tokyo. As a result, the funding for some sports, including badminton, archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, has been cut. However, funding for other sports, such as judo, has been increased. The funding for the five new Olympic sports and two new Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth, England will be demolished to make way for a new six-story, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The development was approved by the council despite objections from English Heritage, who argued that the scale of the project would harm the designated conservation area. The council, however, voted in favor of the project, citing the need to preserve tourism and improve living conditions for older residents.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a soldier in the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was found unconscious in Brecon, Wales, on May 8th. CCTV footage showed him being punched and beaten by Jake Vallely, who was later found guilty of manslaughter. Vallely had been drinking heavily and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of any involvement in the attack. Police called the attack "a despicable act" that shocked the community. Pte Boyd's family described him as a loving and caring person with a promising career ahead of him. They said Vallely had created a void in their family that will never be filled.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, resigned after a major error occurred during the local elections. Voters were turned away from polling stations because their names were not on the voter registration list. An independent investigation has been launched to determine the cause of the error and will conclude by the end of May.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1. Josh Gillies scored the first goal for Gateshead with a free kick, but Wrexham tied the game with a free kick of their own by Sean Newton. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead by heading a cross from Craig Baxter. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby was pleased with his team's performance, especially in the second half, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills was disappointed with his team's second half performance.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks 96 countries based on the social and economic well-being of their citizens over 60. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan and Mozambique rank lowest.

The Scottish government will have Â£390 million more in spending available to them next year, according to the UK government. However, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. The Scottish government is determined to defend and protect the key priorities that the people of Scotland expect them to deliver on, such as schools, hospitals, and the police service. The UK government's Scotland Office said the Scottish government should focus more on gearing up for its new powers and getting the best for Scotland, rather than grievance.

Changing Places toilets are larger than standard accessible toilets and include features like a hoist and a bench to help people with severe disabilities change. Campaigners are calling for these toilets to be made compulsory in larger buildings like shopping centers, cinemas, and sports stadiums. Currently, they are only recommended in building regulations. The lack of Changing Places toilets can cause stress and isolation for families with disabled members, as they may have to change their loved ones in unsuitable locations. However, there are some positive examples of businesses that have installed Changing Places toilets, such as Arsenal Football Club, and individuals who have created "pop-up" Changing Places facilities.

A group of Italian consumer organizations filed a formal complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees. The complaint alleges that McDonald's uses its dominant market position to force franchisees into long-term contracts, preventing them from switching to competitors. The complaint also claims that franchisees are forced to lease premises from McDonald's at above-market rates, leading to higher prices for consumers. The European Commission will investigate the allegations and may launch a formal investigation if they are found to be credible.

Thirteen-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh began on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff. The campaign has gone viral, with the hashtag being used by people all over the world. A mystery donor paid for a billboard with the hashtag to be erected at Holywood playing fields.

The British government is closing Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Wales, as part of a larger restructuring of the UK military. The decision has been met with criticism from local MP Chris Davies, who argues that the closure will negatively impact the local economy and disrespect the site's history. The closure is part of a larger plan to create a specialist light infantry center at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan.

The UK fishing industry is facing uncertainty as the country prepares to leave the EU. The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report that examines the risks and opportunities for the industry. The report warns that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal. The report also suggests that the UK should retain many elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) post-Brexit, including the use of scientific advice for setting quotas. However, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about the future, believing that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats.

The US government has access to a vast amount of personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. This access is facilitated by the Prism program, which allows the NSA to access the servers of major technology companies like Google, Facebook, and Microsoft. The US government has confirmed that it requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call duration, location, and phone numbers. While the US government claims that these surveillance activities are necessary for national security, critics argue that they violate privacy rights and that the government's access to data is more extensive than necessary. The US Patriot Act of 2001 gave American authorities new powers over European data stored in the US, raising concerns about the impact on data protection laws in other countries.

OpenAI, a new research venture backed by prominent figures like Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, aims to advance digital intelligence in a way that benefits humanity. The venture is free from financial obligations, allowing its research to focus on positive human impact. OpenAI acknowledges the potential risks of AI, but believes it should be an extension of human will and distributed widely.

Ben Parkinson, a British soldier who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26th. He has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but the site limits friend associations to 5,000 per personal page. Parkinson's mother, Diane, said the responses to his torch carrying had been "phenomenal" and that Ben was really "buoyed up" by the support and friendship he had been shown. She said that Ben's Facebook page had received 19,000 hits on an update and that the family had received a large amount of mail and emails. Facebook suggested that Parkinson consider having a page instead of a profile or use subscribe so that people can see his public updates without actually becoming a friend.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the United States remained at 15%, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. The median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased for the first time since 1993. However, the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7% from 16.3%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, signed a new contract with Lancashire that will keep him with the team until 2019. Buttler, who is known for his short-format skills, has scored three of England's fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. He will return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates, HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, are currently docked in Portsmouth Harbour. The government's Disposal Services Authority is selling the ships, with bids due in late February and March. The government wants to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capabilities.  Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports this but also wants to see at least one frigate saved from the scrapyard, possibly as a reef or diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence has said it will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer.

Fiji has experienced significant political and racial tensions since 1987, leading to a series of coups and international isolation. These events have negatively impacted the economy, particularly tourism, and caused a decline in Fiji's international reputation. The country's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the former now constituting a slight majority. Despite a diverse economy, Fiji faces persistent trade and budget deficits, making it heavily reliant on foreign aid.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile of chemical weapons, but Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad claims that two shipments were attacked by terrorists on their way to the port of Latakia. He insists that Syria is committed to destroying its chemical weapons and is doing its best to comply with the timetable. The US has condemned Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, but Mr. Mekdad denies that the government has targeted civilians. The Syrian government also denies that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims that rebels have taken control of the prison, freeing hundreds of detainees.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize shortlist includes six novels: *The Lives of Others* by Jhumpa Lahiri, *J* by Howard Jacobson, *How To Be Both* by Ali Smith, *To Rise Again at a Decent Hour* by Joshua Ferris, *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves* by Karen Joy Fowler, and *The Narrow Road to the Deep North* by Richard Flanagan. The winner will be announced on Tuesday night at London's Guildhall. The prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The shortlist includes three British writers, two Americans, and one Australian. The book with the highest sales is *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves* by Karen Joy Fowler.  *The Lives of Others* by Jhumpa Lahiri is the favorite to win.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing a court ruling that lifted a ban on his name being published in the media. The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant the appeal. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of PJS's alleged extramarital activities, but he argues he has a right to privacy. The Court of Appeal ruled that the ban should be lifted because the story has already been published in other countries and online, making it impossible to maintain confidentiality.

Fosse Park, a shopping center near junction 21 of the M1, was recently purchased for ÃÂ£345.5m. The new owners plan to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units. They see the shopping center as an investment opportunity and want to improve the overall look and feel of the area, particularly the common areas and facilities.

Disney's live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" was initially banned in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" in the film, which features LeFou, Gaston's sidekick, struggling with his feelings for Gaston. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) eventually approved the film with a minor edit to the "gay moment," but the release date has yet to be announced. The decision to review the film sparked criticism from many Malaysians, who felt the ban was unnecessary and hypocritical.

Southampton City Council estimates that there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area, despite the fact that landlords who rent to more than three unrelated people are required to obtain a license. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for not obtaining a license. The council has designated certain areas in Southampton where HMO licenses are required, including Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling, Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett. Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan said that tenants in HMOs often express concerns about eviction and living in poorly maintained properties.

Following the Irish election, Fine Gael and Fianna FÃ¡il are attempting to form a coalition government to avoid a second election. Fianna FÃ¡il has agreed to facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government. The main point of contention is water charges, with Fianna FÃ¡il wanting their immediate removal and Fine Gael seeing a role for them. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being proposed.

A fire broke out on the car deck of the Sorrento ferry, which was traveling to Valencia from Mallorca. The fire quickly spread, forcing the evacuation of all passengers and crew onto lifeboats. Three people were injured, one seriously, and were transported to a hospital by helicopter. The fire was so intense that the ferry may sink. The passengers were rescued by other ships and are expected to arrive in Palma de Mallorca within a few hours. Psychologists will be at the port to provide counseling.

The Electoral Commission found that 38 MPs reported cases of people, including students, claiming to have voted twice in the June 8th election. The Commission recommended that electoral registers be better connected to identify duplicate entries. The Commission also stated that the online registration system should include a verification function to prevent duplicate applications. The Commission found that the number of duplicate applications was significant, with estimates ranging from 30% to 70% in different areas. The Commission also stated that voting twice in a general election is a criminal offense. Labour warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote, arguing that a blanket ban on being registered at two addresses would exclude those who need to be registered in two places for work or study.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player and star at the University of Nebraska, was found dead in his prison cell. Phillips had a history of legal troubles, including assault charges and a conviction for driving his car into a group of teenagers. He was recently accused of killing his former cellmate and was awaiting trial. Phillips was serving a 30-year sentence.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and the 30th mascot ram of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for "good behaviour". He joined the regiment in 2014 and has his own army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during mating season. He has participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a thrilling Europa League quarterfinal match. The victory was a testament to manager Jurgen Klopp's ability to inspire his players and turn doubters into believers. Liverpool's comeback from a 2-0 deficit was a remarkable feat, showcasing their resilience and determination. The match was a display of both teams' talent and passion, with Dortmund's early dominance countered by Liverpool's relentless pursuit of victory. The win has given Liverpool a renewed sense of confidence and a chance to return to the Champions League.

The UK government met with representatives from Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland to discuss Brexit negotiations. The UK government plans to hold monthly meetings to share information and analysis with the devolved administrations. The Scottish government wants more transparency from the UK government about its plans, including whether it will remain in the single market or the customs union. The Scottish government will oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal of the High Court judgment on how Article 50 will be triggered.

A team of scientists at the University of Nottingham are studying a flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four clones of Dolly the sheep, to determine if cloning affects the aging process and overall health of the animals. The scientists are particularly interested in whether cloned animals are more susceptible to age-related diseases like cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The study is ongoing, but the cloned sheep, now approaching their ninth and tenth birthdays, appear to be healthy. The results of the study, which could have significant implications for the future of cloning, will be published next week.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes at York. She will now go to Chantilly for the French Oaks, while Gosden will focus on Enable and Coronet for the Epsom Oaks. Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will decide whether he runs after walking the course.

The British pound has been fluctuating against the dollar and euro, with investors becoming increasingly uncertain about the outcome of the upcoming referendum on the UK's membership in the EU. The "volatility index," which measures investor uncertainty, has reached levels last seen during the 2008 financial crisis. Recent polls have shown a tightening race between the Leave and Remain campaigns, leading to increased volatility in the pound. Hedge funds have been placing bets on the pound's further decline, and the markets are on high alert for a Brexit. The economic impact of a potential Leave vote has also been blamed for a significant drop in Asian stock markets.

Braintree Town, a part-time team, lost to Barrow, extending their losing streak to three games. Despite the loss, manager Cowley remains optimistic about his team's performance, noting their remarkable season so far.  Braintree is currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside of the play-off spots.

In April 2015, Northern Ireland will transfer planning decision-making power from the Planning Service to local councils. This change will give elected politicians the final say on developments in their areas. While some, like Michael Corr, see this as an opportunity for local councils to develop their own community plans, others, like James Orr of Friends of the Earth, are concerned about potential discrimination and a lack of transparency. Orr worries that the close relationships between developers and political parties could lead to a "laissez-faire system" where certain communities are favored over others. Friends of the Earth advocates for increased transparency in political donations to ensure fairness and accountability in the new planning system.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times by an air gun in Winchburgh, Scotland. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA. Teenie's back leg had to be amputated, and she is now learning to walk again. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to contact them. The incident has reignited calls for the Scottish government to implement licensing for air guns, which was opposed by a majority of respondents in a recent consultation.

Liverpool signed Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for an undisclosed fee, making him the club's second most expensive signing. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, is Liverpool's seventh summer signing. The club is hoping Benteke will help them score more goals after struggling last season.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that while tablet computers are increasingly common in schools, there is no clear evidence that they improve academic performance. The study, which looked at 671 schools, found that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets, with 9% of schools providing a tablet for every student. While head teachers reported positive impacts, such as increased motivation and family involvement, researchers could not isolate the impact of technology on academic achievement. The study also found that young people are heavily immersed in technology, with many taking internet-connected devices to bed for social media and other activities.

The Museum of Liverpool is hosting an exhibition called "Growing Up in the City" which features 25 photographs that capture the lives of children in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, showcases how childhood has changed over the years, including the shift from children working to children playing in the streets. The exhibition is on display until September 25th.

Barrow centre-back Anderson, 27, has joined Torquay United, while striker Keating, 21, has also joined the club. Anderson has played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, while Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Torquay manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and Keating as hungry to prove himself. Torquay is currently four points above the relegation zone.

Bolivia has passed a new law that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental consent. The law also sets a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The law was passed to address the needs of Bolivia, one of the poorest countries in South America, where over 500,000 children work to supplement their family income. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) is studying the legislation to determine if it violates international regulations on child labor.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress, recently suffered a heart attack. She experienced chest pain, nausea, and fever after helping a woman in her home. O'Donnell researched her symptoms online and took aspirin before visiting a cardiologist who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. She revealed that she did not call emergency services but urged her readers to be aware of heart attack symptoms and to call 911 if they experience them.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a 16-year-old boy from Harrow, was stabbed and killed in an alleyway in Kenton, London, after attending a party. Police believe he was not involved in an earlier altercation with a group of youths who were denied entry to the party, but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, along with two boys aged 15 and 16. A third boy, aged 14, was arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark has implemented a new system for diagnosing cancer patients, which has resulted in improved survival rates. The system has three routes: a fast-track diagnosis and treatment route for patients with "alarm" symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. The system has led to better organization of how patients are diagnosed within existing resources and has helped to break down barriers between GPs and specialists.

Powys County Council will take over the role of regulating estate agents in Wales, issuing warnings and banning orders against those who act dishonestly or break estate agent laws. The council will receive Â£170,000 a year to carry out the work, which was previously done by the OFT. People with complaints about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will refer cases to Powys if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached.

The Nuffield Trust has recommended that the NHS reshape its workforce to better utilize its 1.3 million employees. The report highlights examples of nurses filling in for doctors and pharmacists, which the report argues is a positive development due to the changing nature of healthcare. The report also acknowledges that funding will be needed to implement these changes.
